characters: ABOUT THE MOUTH OF THE TUNNEL
WHAT THEY SEE ON THE EDGE OF THE GULLY

dialogues.speaker: H. G. WELLS' BOOK
dialogues.text: We see the colorful cover, then the first page. A VOICE with a Wells-like accent quotes the opening words:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: No one would have believed, in the first decades of the twentieth century...

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The planet Mars shows just above the spires and roof- tops of a city on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (Continuing) ...that human affairs were being watched keenly and closely by intelligences greater than man's. Mars is picked out of the sky and brought to the screen as if by some enormous telescope with an infinite field. It becomes a small ball. Enlarges to a pallid disk. Comes to moon size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one gave a thought to the older worlds as a source of human danger. Yet across the gulf of space, on the planet Mars... Now Mars has grown big and ruddy-colored. Mysterious canals revealed. Vegetation patches shadowy. One thin polar cap shimmering.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Intellects vast and cool and unsym- pathetic regarded our earth with envious eyes, slowly and surely drawing their plans against us.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: seen in space with its halo of atmosphere, beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Few voices were ever raised in warning as, with infinite compla- cency, men went to and fro over this globe, busy about their affairs.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF THUMBNAIL FLASHES, (STOCK)
dialogues.text: designed to get over the enjoyment of life on this earth today. a. Gay, seven-piece Dixieland band, whapping out a fast tempo in a night club. Grand National at Aintree. Parade at the Carnival de Nice. Gambling in a casino. Trooping the Colors, London. Packed stadium and a smashing football game. Geisha party in Tokyo.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (Over f. and g.) It did not occur to mankind that a swift fate might be hanging over us. Or that, from the blackness of outer space, we were being scrutinized  A-5a. and studied. During this, CAMERA MOVES IN on the Geisha girls. We are CLOSE on the round casing of one of their strange- sounding instruments as we -

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The planet as we saw it before. CAMERA MOVES IN until the planet is huge on the screen. Strange and baleful.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Mars is more than one hundred and forty million miles from the sun, and for centuries it has been in the last stages of exhaustion. Its rocks have absorbed almost all oxygen from its air, turning them red.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: A geometric pattern of great canals joins in the far distance to center on a Martian metropolis. High atop a tower a light pulsates rhythmically.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Most of its water has gone. At night, temperatures drop to more than one hundred and twenty degrees below zero, even at the equator.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF DISSOLVES
dialogues.text: CAMERA FLOATS through the blackness of space, pick- ing up each succeeding spectacle. a. Our solar system, as seen from Mars. The sun golden. Mercury ruddy and hot. Venus beau- tiful, bright. Saturn with its tinted rings and moons. Jupiter big, cloudy, with four moons. Uranus and Neptune both greenish- yellow, toxic. And Pluto far away.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: The inhabitants of this dying planet looked across space with instruments and intelli- gences of which we have scarcely dreamed... CAMERA MOVES IN on Pluto, dim in outer space. VOICE (Cont'd) Â«searching for another World to which they  could migrate. They could not go to Pluto, outermost of all the planets, and so cold that its atmosphere lies frozen on its surface. CAMERA PICKS UP Neptune and Uranus, clouded giants with poison-colored atmospheres. VOICE (Cont'd) They couldn't go to Neptune or Uranus - twin worlds in eternal night and perpetual cold. Each surrounded by an unbreathable atmosphere full of methane gas and ammonia vapor. The Martians considered Saturn. b. Saturnian landscape. Midnight-blue space-sky crossed by merging rings of cosmic dust. Bright-edged, full of color and marvelous to see.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: An attractive world with its many moons and beautiful rings of cosmic dust. But its temperature is close to two hundred and seventy degrees below zero, and ice lies fifteen thousand miles deep on its surface. Their nearest world was giant Jupiter... c. Effect Pan Shot - Landscape of Jupiter An incredible world. Cliffs flaming at the tops and spilling into fuming lakes. Everywhere the same process repeating itself.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Where there are titanic cliffs of lava and ice, with hydrogen flaming at the tops. Where the atmospheric pressure is terrible - thousands of pounds to the square inch. On Mars it is only four pounds. They couldn't go there. Nor to Venus, which has no oxygen and no water. Nor could they go to Mercury nearest planet to the sun. da. Effect - Mercurian Landscape. A glaring sun is enormous in a dark sky, stars visible near it. The land is heat-hazed, waterless, fissured. Volcanic cones and lava pools.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: It has no air. And the temperature at its equator is that of molten lead. Of all the worlds that the intelligences on Mars could see and study ..... e. North American continent, seen from a great height, showing clouds, forests,  glistening lakes and rivers.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: ...only our own warm earth was green with vegetation, bright with water, and possessed a cloudy atmosphere eloquent of fertility. Â£. Sky full of stars above a small town and hills....Mars low in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: At the time of our nearest approach to the orbit of Mars, during a pleasant summer season.... Far away in the sky we see a falling star.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: ...in the late hours of a Friday evening...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire LOOKOUT and his deputy, FIDDLER HAWKINS - round-faced, hearty - are seated at a small table by a big window, playing cards. Behind them is an Osborne fire-finder. On a shelf are cans of tobacco, fruit, coffee, a pipe, magazines. The lookout's glance goes upward to the sky and is held there.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The meteor leaves a thin, luminous streak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near a stream, beyond which, through trees, is a broad meadow. Small tent. A lantern hangs froma branch. Waders hang on another limb. Beyond, in the meadow, rests a small Stinson cabin plane. Near the tent, a convertible is parked. A small, round, bald man - BILDERBECK - is frying trout in a pan over the fire, his hatband decorated with pretty flies. A younger man - PRYOR - is coming from the direction of the stream, with clean- ed trout strung on a stick. A third man - CLAYTON FORRESTER - butch haircut and hornrims - is sitting on a log, working over his tackle, looking skyward. He calls. The others look with him.  10. 11. 12. 13. 14. 15.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: It is large. Its bright trail is thicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small-town, California audience is breaking after the last show. Among them are two young parents, the father carrying a sleeping baby. Teen-agers head for the ice-cream parlor next door. A lost kid is bawling on the sidewalk. A man on a ladder is adding âHeld Over" to the marquee which features "Samson and Delilah." Like most the others, he is looking at the sky. The CAMERA PICKS UP SYLVIA VAN BUREN - twenty-six, normal, nice, admiring the sleeping baby. Near her is PASTOR COLLINS - white-haired. He is gazing at the sky as he touches Sylvia's arm. She looks and stands staring.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Altogether larger now, rushing aslant down the sky.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: A group has formed on the sidewalk by Sylvia and the Pastor - WASH PERRY, big teeth, no hat, shirt-sleeves. "ZIPPY', a clumsy youth. SALVADOR, a swarthy, good- natured Mexican. ALONZO HOGUE, local realtor, chews tobacco. GROUP - ad libs Is that a fireball or somep'n? Boy, that's big ! - Maybe it's a comet - looks like it's coming right at us!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Huge, brilliant, fusing and frightening. Its tail seems to spurt more brilliantly as the meteor vanishes beyond buildings and dark trees.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: looking o.s. at the meteor. Pryor slaps a mosquito.

dialogues.speaker: BILDERBECK
dialogues.text: That was a meteorite - (Returning to fire) - burning itself out.  16. 17.

dialogues.speaker: PRYOR
dialogues.text: (Unstringing fish) There's never much left of when they hit the ground. "em Clayton turns after them, then pauses, looking again toward where the meteor landed.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Everyone staring o.s. Fascinated. A little alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: That had me scared! - Wonder where it lit? - Miles away, I betcha.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPY
dialogues.text: Let's go find it, huh?

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: That probably dropped half way to Pomona!...What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: It was nearer than that.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPY
dialogues.text: I'm gonna see. Who's coming? He starts out. Other teen-agers follow him.

dialogues.speaker: FORESTRY LOOKOUT POST
dialogues.text: Lookout at the phone. Fiddler, crouched, sighting the firefinder, still holding his cards.

dialogues.speaker: LOOKOUT
dialogues.text: (At phone) This is Pine Summit. I've got a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER
dialogues.text: (Reading firefinder) One sixty... thirty.

dialogues.speaker: LOOKOUT
dialogues.text: (At phone) Azimuth reading - one hundred sixty degrees thirty minutes. (Gazing out window) About ten miles. It must-a hit red hot! Fiddler straightens, sneaks a glance at the Lookout's cards, then studies his own.  18. 19. 20. 21.

dialogues.speaker: LOOKOUT
dialogues.text: (At phone) You better get somepin out there - it's started a blaze already!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS FAST on a small forestry service tanker coming down the road, red light blinking. Scattered trees and scrub in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road curves near low, sharp little hills. The ground is rough, scattered with prickly pear, yucca, small bushes, stunted trees. At the foot of the hills is a fairly deep gully. Bushes, grass, small trees are burning all around this. The tanker is on the scene. The fire-crew is being helped by teen- agers from Linda Rosa and men from nearby farms.

dialogues.speaker: AROUND THE GULLY AREA
dialogues.text: a. Men dipping sacks into a tub of water, running to fire in b.g. Zippy and others slapping out flames with wet gunny sacks. b. Uniformed Ranger attacking burning bushes with a spray extinguisher. Two men hacking furiously with brush hooks. The tanker moving along an edge of the fire. Two men riding it, spraying flames. The ranger surveys the fire, then turns to a small Forestry pickup truck in f.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ranger puts his extinguisher in the truck, picks up the radio transmitter, pushes the switch.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: (Into mike) Number three to. D.O....Number three to D.O.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE
dialogues.text: D.O. to number three..come in.  2la. 22.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: We're getting this under control. Won't need any more help. Over.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE
dialogues.text: Okay. Send the tanker in, but you stand by until that thing cools off. Over.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: I think somebody ought to check on it. Over.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE
dialogues.text: Well, there's some fellows fishing at Pine Summit might be interested. They probably saw it come down. I'll let âem know...What's it look like? The Ranger glances in the direction of the meteor.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: At one end of the gully. Mostly buried, but a thick, blunt, rounded end shows out of the loose sand and rock. Massive. On its surface are red-hot blurs, like fire under ashes. RANGERS VOICE (0.s.) Can't get near enough to see it very well - it's too hot -- but it's a whale of a size!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton Forrester, Pryor, Bilderbeck, sitting by the fire, eating. All the makings of a meal are on a nearby box: coffee, rolls, butter, honey, canned fruit, fried tomatoes. Extra helpings of fish simmer in the pan. A beat-up station wagon lurches out of the darkness in b.g. The three look up, surprised. Fiddler, the deputy ranger from the lookout post, alights

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER
dialogues.text: (Calling) I got a message for you. (Moving in) You're the guys from Pacific-Tech, ain't you?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Right.  23.

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER
dialogues.text: (Eyeing pan) Looks like the fishing was good.

dialogues.speaker: BILDERBECK
dialogues.text: Have some?

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER
dialogues.text: (Eagerly - hitching over a box) Well...I might just do that...!

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Fiddler reaches for a plate, then helps himself liberally to everything in sight - most of the remaining fish, two rolls, a hunk of butter, coffee. The others stop eating and watch him.

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER
dialogues.text: (Talking between grabs) It's about that meteor. They say it's a whopper. The District Officer phoned us at the lookout up on the summit. Thought you might be interested... It's ten or twelve miles from here - over by Linda Rosa.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Are they sure it's a meteor? It didn't come down like one.

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER
dialogues.text: (Gesturing with fish on his fork) That's right - came down in kinda spurts, didn't it? (Gobbles fish) You fellers'll have to figure it out. You're scientists (Puts down fork- plucks cigarette from Bilderbeck's shirt pocket) All I know - they say it's as big as a house and practically red hot.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (To Bilderbeck) I'd like to borrow your car and take a look at it in the morning. Bilderbeck nods. Pryor looks toward the plane in the meadow in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: PRYOR
dialogues.text: We ought to get back to Pasadena.  24. 25. (Gesturing) I can fly Bilderbeck down in your plane.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Okay, if he's willing. (Grinning) The insurance is paid up. Bilderbeck takes a stick from the fire and holds it out to Fiddler, who is eating again, holding the cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: BILDERBECK
dialogues.text: Want a light?

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER
dialogues.text: (Glancing) No. I'll smoke it later. He tucks the cigarette behind his ear and goes on eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The meteor still lies in the gully, heat-hazed, a little thin smoke rising, burned grass and bushes in b.g. On the bank of the gully, a woman is kodaking two kids against the b.g. of the meteor. Beyond, a few old cars and a station wagon have pulled off the dirt road; nearby is Pastor Collinsâ three-year- old Plymouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sylvia is sitting behind the wheel in Pastor Collinsâ car. The Pastor is talking to the uniformed Ranger. With them are Wash Perry, Alonzo Hogue, Salvador, Fiddler. A handful of people is scattered in b.g., eyeing the meteor, talking about it.

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: (Pointing) It must have hit way up there, and then skidded along the gully. When it stopped, all that loose earth and stuff shook down over it.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: It's probably a stray from a swarm of meteors.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO HOGUE
dialogues.text: (To Pastor)  26. I reckon most of it's buried.

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER
dialogues.text: That's twelve feet thick, easy. Maybe more.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO HOGUE
dialogues.text: Meteors always run heavy. They won't be able to haul this one away to no museum! (Speculatively) It'll be a real good attraction for Sunday drivers.

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY
dialogues.text: Better'n a lion farm or a snake pit. We won't have to feed it!

dialogues.speaker: SALVADOR
dialogues.text: We sell the tamales, enchiladas - hot dogs!

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER
dialogues.text: Ice cream, cold drinks, souvenirs!

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: I think we should put up a few picnic tables...

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO HOGUE
dialogues.text: (Quickly) Naw, naw -- then they'd bring their own lunches!

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: "BUCK' MONAHAN - in service station overalls - passes the group, carrying a shovel, headed for the meteor. In b.g. a convertible pulls off the dirt road.

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER
dialogues.text: What's the idea, Buck? Gonna dig for gold?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: (Indicating meteor) This is gonna be like having a gold mine in our own back yard!

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLLINS
dialogues.text: (To Sylvia) I'm going to get a closer look at it. The men come forward, PAST CAMERA. Sylvia pulls out the car keys, reaches for her purse. The convertible bumps up, stops. The back is loaded with camping  27. 28. 29. gear and clustered fishing rods. Clayton Forrester gets out, looking toward the gully. Sylvia glances at him as she starts after the others, opening her purse. A faint ticking SOUND comes overscene.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Is that it over there?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Searching purse) Yes...ugly looking, isn't it.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: as Buck comes on toward the meteor with his shovel. Pastor Collins and the others pause to watch him.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: (Calling back) It's still pretty darned hot!

dialogues.speaker: BUCK AND METEOR
dialogues.text: He shields his face, reaching out, probing with his shovel trying to determine the size of the meteor. TWO SHOT - CLAYTON AND SYLVIA - HIS CAR IN B.G. He is looking toward the gully. She now has a ciga- rette. They pause as she begins looking for matches.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Rummaging in purse) Did you see it come down?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Absently, studying gully and meteor) Yes...I was fishing up in the hills.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Glancing back at car) You must have caught plenty with all that tackle!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Glancing, smiling) Oh - there were three of us. (Starting forward) The others flew back in my plane. (Pausing again - looking os.) I don't understand why a meteor this size didn't make a bigger crater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Definite) It hit sideways and skidded in. He glances at her, a little amused. She catches his eye. SYLVIA (Cont'd) (Easily) At least, that's what I think. I don't really know. (At purse) But the Ranger says a scientist is coming from Pacific-Tech. He'll tell us. (And then) Clayton Forrester. Ever hear of him?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Looking o.s. - changing the subject) What's that fellow over there trying to do - dig it out?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Over him, not hearing) He's top man in astro and nuclear physics. He knows all about meteors!

dialogues.speaker: MOVING
dialogues.text: FAVORING Clayton, as they move on. Clayton is secretly amused, and a little flattered.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: You seem to know a lot about him.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Well, I did a thesis on modern scien- tists - working for my Masters degree.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Did it do you any good?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Why, sure -- I got it! Do you have a match?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I don't smoke.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Going on, enthusiastic) Forrester's the man behind the new atomic engines. They had him on the cover of 'Time'. You've got to rate  to get that!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Aw, he isn't that good...!

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Protesting, stopping) How can you say that when you don't know him!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I do know him...slightly.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Interested at once) What's he like?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Like...ah... Clayton hesitates, points to himself. She stares, then gets it. For a moment she is provoked, then she bursts naturally into laughter. He laughs with her.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Well, you certainly don't look like yourself in that get-up! (Laughing still, offering hand) But I am happy to meet you anyway. I'm Sylvia Van Buren. I teach Library Science over at USC.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I didn't know how to stop you...!

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I might have recognized you without the beard. And you didn't wear glasses on the 'Time' cover!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: They're really for long distance. When I want to look at something close... (Removing glasses, bending to her) I take them off.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Buck is backing off, blowing running with sweat.  Clayton and Sylvia approach from b.g.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: (Kidding) You gonna quit? -- Roll up your sleeves, Buck! -- We thought you were gonna dig it out by yourself. Buck joins the group, wiping sweat. CAMERA MOVES IN as Clayton comes up with Sylvia.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Boy - you could fry eggs on it!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: All that sand will keep the heat in for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (To Pastor Collins) Uncle Matthew...this is Dr. Clayton Forrester. (To Clayton) My uncle - Dr. Matthew Collins, pastor of the Community Church.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: (Offering hand, pleased) Well-1...how do you do, Dr. Forrester!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Courteous - warm) How dtyou do, sir? SHERIFF'S VOICE (0O.s.) (Excitedly calling) Hey - you! All look quickly.

dialogues.speaker: MOVING SHOT
dialogues.text: CAMERA is CLOSE and ANGLED DOWN in the back of the car. Tucked along fishing and camping gear alongside a box of iced trout is an impressive Geiger counter, chattering furiously. A signal light is flashing rapidly. The Sheriff's hands reach for it. CAMERA MOVES BACK and his face comes into SCENE, looking down at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: (Yelling off) What you got in here, feller?...It's ticking like a bomb! The SHOT WIDENS as Clayton enter with Pastor Collins,  Sylvia, the Ranger and others. Clayton reaches into the car and picks up a short pole-meter attached to the counter. He swings it around. The clicking slows. He lifts the counter out, points the pole- meter at the gully. The light flashes become a rapid blur, brilliant. The chattering increases to a high- pitched buzz.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (To Sheriff) This is a Geiger counter for detecting radio-activity. We did a little sur- veying while we were up in the hills. (Above SOUND of the counter - looking o.s.) It's that meteor.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: It's radio-active?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Look at this thing -- goinâ crazy! He reaches for the Geiger. Clayton lets him have it and remains looking toward the gully. The SOUND of the Geiger counter continues over SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Puzzled) It's difficult to account for a reaction like that!

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: (Moving in) Maybe we ought to keep people away from it, huh?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Quietly - thinking) Might be a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: I'll post two-three deputies. They can watch it don't start any more fires.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: You know, that meteor's either very light - which is unheard of! - or else it's hollow somehow. If it were solid and heavy it would have made a tremendous crater when it landed. (Suddenly) I think I'll stay around until it cools off.  35. 36. (To Sylvia) If you could tell me of a place in town -- (Strokes his chin) -- I'd like to clean up.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: I'd be delighted if you'd stay at my house, Doctor Forrester.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Thank you. (Looks toward meteor) It probably won't be cool for another twenty-four hours. (To Sylvia) What do people do around here on a Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Returning his smile) They don't do much of anything...!

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: There's a square dance at the social hall this evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very CLOSE on Fiddler Hawkins, sweating, calling the dance, holding violin.

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER
dialogues.text: (Raucous) A hickory limp and an ole burned stump - Go meet your honey and everybody jump! CAMERA PULLS BACK. Fiddler wears Levis, embroidered shirt. With him is a guitar player in a dress-up Western outfit. Everybody's stomping. Girls in tight bodices, swirling skirts, bows in their hair, Men in T-shirts, suits and shirtsleeves, Levis, fron- tier pants and cowboy boots. FIDDLER (Cont'd) Now promenade two and promenade four - Promenade that pretty gal all around the floor. CAMERA PICKS UP Clayton and Sylvia promenading arm in arm in a SET which includes the Sheriff. Clayton  37. 38. 39. 40. wears tan gabardine slacks, fresh shirt, tie with a Western motif. He is clean-shaven. Sylvia wears a forget-me-not cotton print, with style to it. Clayton is not an accomplished square dancer, but he isn't bad. Sylvia checks his wrong move in response to the next rollicking call. He laughs. They both enjoy this.

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Now face your lady and make a bow, She's a pretty one you'll allow! Point the heel and point the toe - Now you're makinâ a do-si-do. Mom - there's a chicken in the bread-bin A-peckin' at the dough! One more change and on we go.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: No smoke now. Its appearance is otherwise unchanged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wash Perry, Alonzo Hogue, Salvador. Behind them, two old cars are parked not far from the gully. A small fire burns on the open ground. The three men step forward toward the gully, peering through the dark- ness. Salvador switches on a flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Still, ominous, as the flashlight hits it.

dialogues.speaker: WASH, SALVADOR, ALONZO
dialogues.text: They MOVE toward the gully, Salvador playing the flashlight ahead. As they pause on the edge of the gully, he cuts the light.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO HOGUE
dialogues.text: Looks almost cold now, don't it?

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY
dialogues.text: That won't start no more fires. We might's well go home.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO HOGUE
dialogues.text: (Spitting - starting away) Yeah. No sense stayin' out here.

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY
dialogues.text: (Following him)  Let's go. As they start away, CAMERA MOVES CLOSE on Salvador. He raises the flashlight for a last look at the meteor and pops it on directly into the LENSE.

dialogues.speaker: SALVADOR
dialogues.text: (In alarm) Hey - it's movin"!

dialogues.speaker: THE THREE
dialogues.text: Alonzo Hogue and Wash Perry, f.g., whirl and go back to Salvador. Beyond them in the gully, the meteor is lit by Salvador's flashlight. Something is moving on top of it. 4la. CLOSE THREE SHOT Eyes popping as they stare off at the meter. 4lb. SPECIAL EFFECT - METEOR Thin gray clinker is dropping off in flakes. The rounded top is turning. A thread of bright metal appears between the moving top and the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start to back off.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO HOGUE
dialogues.text: It's a bomb!

dialogues.speaker: SALVADOR
dialogues.text: It don't go off last night -- it's going off now!

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY
dialogues.text: It's an enemy sneak attack. Let's get outta here!

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO HOGUE
dialogues.text: (Stopping them) Wait a minute - wait a minute!.... Bombs don't unscrew.

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY
dialogues.text: (Backing away again) It's no meteor, that's for sure!
(Backing away too) Darnedest thing I ever saw - the way that's unscrewing! Salvador only stares as they all retreat.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY BACK. The top segment of the meteor is turning steadily. The band of bright metal is rapidly growing wider, serrated, greenish- white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring Sylvia, sitting on a bench against the wall, fanning herself with a lace handkerchief. Clayton comes to her between guys, wiping sweat. Girls fix- ing shaken hair-do's. People arguing about who ruined the square. Clayton has two soft drinks with straws, hands one bottle to Sylvia, drops on the bench beside her. Fiddler's VOICE comes over SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Taking bottle) Thank you, Doctor Forrester... (Glancing) You having fun?

dialogues.speaker: DANCE FLOOR
dialogues.text: SHOOTING past Clayton and Sylvia. He is sweating. Beyond them, hearty dancers are going to town.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Yes. And you know what I was thinking? (Wiping sweat - eyeing dancers) If we could gather all the energy expended in just one square dance, we could send that meteor back to where it came from.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES IN slowly. The bright band of metal  48.
is now almost two feet wide. Suddenly the rotating section falls away like a shell, uncovering bright metal within the opening.

dialogues.speaker: WASH, SALVADOR
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES WITH THEM as they inch forward toward the gully. A faint, reddish light catches their faces. Salvador flicks the spotlight on.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The metal sheath within the opening parts, shutter- like, allowing vivid, reddish light to glow upward from the interior. A HISSING SOUND comes from the meteor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare, fascinated. The SOUND dies away.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The light in the opening dims. Something begins to appear from inside, revolving about, making a WHINING SOUND. Dimly seen, it emerges. It is flattened, hooded, with faintly-luminous openings -- almost cobra-like. It turns as if scanning the area -- snout glittering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wash, Alonzo and Salvador move forward cautiously, warily watching the meteor.

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY
dialogues.text: Must be somebody in there.

dialogues.speaker: SALVADOR
dialogues.text: Who? Where d'you think they come from!

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY
dialogues.text: How would I know...!

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO HOGUE
dialogues.text: (Significantly) I read someplace - Mars is near the earth right now.  They look at him - all getting the same idea. ALONZO HOGUE (Cont'd) Happens every eighteen or twenty years, they say. (Softly) Men from Mars - whaddya think?

dialogues.speaker: SALVADOR
dialogues.text: (Uneasily) Maybe these are not men - not like us.

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY
dialogues.text: Everything human don't have to look like you and me....

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO HOGUE
dialogues.text: If it's men from Mars, we ought to let 'em know we're friendly!

dialogues.speaker: SALVADOR
dialogues.text: (Quick - warning) Don't fool around with something when we don't know what it is!

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY
dialogues.text: We'd be the first to make contact with 'em -- see?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO HOGUE
dialogues.text: (Sharp - suggesting) We'd be in all the papers!

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY
dialogues.text: (Eagerly) Hey, how about that!

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO HOGUE
dialogues.text: We could show 'em we're friendly, huh? Walk out there with a white flag! (Turning) Here - I got an old sugar sack in my car! He leaves the two and runs back to his car and gets the sack and rips it open. He picks up the shovel discarded earlier by Buck, starts to tie the sack to it.

dialogues.speaker: SALVADOR
dialogues.text: (In Â£.g. - to Wash.) What'll we say to âem?

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY
dialogues.text: Welcome to California!
Alonzo Hogue rejoins them, swinging his white flag from side to side as they look off toward the meteor.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Now the shape is extended on a flexible, glistening shaft, revolving about.

dialogues.speaker: THE THREE, (MOVING SHOT)
dialogues.text: They begin to smile as they move forward over the rough ground. Salvador doesn't like it too well, but he comes along.

dialogues.speaker: SALVADOR
dialogues.text: How they gonna understand us?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO HOGUE
dialogues.text: We'll talk in sign language.

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY
dialogues.text: (Bolstering his own feelings) They'll understand us, all right!

dialogues.speaker: SALVADOR
dialogues.text: (Reassuring himself) Sure, sure! Everybody understands you wave the white flag, you wanna be friends. OUT.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Revolving around. Then it seems to zero in the direction of the approaching group. A light begins to flicker within the head mechanism.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: CAMERA FRAMED over the mechanism in f.g. Beyond, on the edge of the gully, the three men spread out. Alonzo holds the flag high. Wash lifts his Panama hat. Salvador waves a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY
dialogues.text: Hey, there - open up!

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO HOGUE
dialogues.text: Come on out! We're friends!  59. 60. 60a.

dialogues.speaker: SALVADOR
dialogues.text: (Nervous - open-armed) That's right! We welcome you.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The glittering light within the hood brightens and begins to glow red and yellow.

dialogues.speaker: WASH PERRY'S VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: We're friends!

dialogues.speaker: SALVADOR'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah - all friends here! A blinding flash - red, orange, yellow, spits from the hooded shape, obliterating everything. An unearthly SCREAM accompanies it.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: A REVERSE ANGLE across Wash Perry, Salvador and Alonzo Hogue to the hooded shape beyond. The blast of the heat-ray - pulsating, glaring - outlines them momentarily as stark silhouettes, then engulfs them in searing flames. As the horrible SCREAMING reaches a crescendo, the men become incandescent, glowing, then crumpling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring Clayton and Sylvia, near the climax of a set.

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Here we come with the old mess wagon, The hind wheel off and the axle dragginâ... Every light cuts off. The music FADES OUT. The sets break up. People bump into one another.

dialogues.speaker: SQUARE DANCERS
dialogues.text: (Ad lib) What's the big idea? - Who's monkey- ing with the lights? - Get your hand outa my pocket! - Where's the fuse box? A girl titters shrilly as a boy hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: No smoochin' in the dark, folks!  61. 62.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR REFRESHMENT COUNTER
dialogues.text: Someone lights a candle and puts it in a bottle. Dancers are milling, laughing, kidding. Zippy is at a pay phone on the wall, between the counter and the door to the street. Clayton and Sylvia move into The Sheriff pushes past them.

dialogues.speaker: FIDDLER
dialogues.text: (At a window) Hey, look! - look! Every light in the town's gone out.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: (To Zippy) Call the electric company. See what happened.

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPY
dialogues.text: (Jogging receiver) The phone's gone dead!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (To Sylvia, glancing) The phone's not on the same circuit as the lights. Shooting out from the refreshment counter, favoring an elderly man and his wife.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MAN
dialogues.text: What they sayin', honey? (Removing ear-plug) Somep'n's gone wrong with my hear- ing aid!

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: Well, we always play âGoodnight, Ladies' at twelve o'clock, anyway. (Reaching for pocket watch) It must be nearly that now - My watch has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: I got the time. (At wrist-watch) No - mine's stopped, too!

dialogues.speaker: ZIPPY
dialogues.text: So's mine!

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: (Looking at watches,  63. 64. 65. shaking them) Jeepers, mine ain't workin', either! What is this? - Hey, look, the clock's stopped - My watch isn't going - How could this happen! GROUP - CLAYTON, SYLVIA, SHERIFF, PASTOR COLLINS IN F.G. Clayton looks at his watch, then at Sylvia's. He slips off his own.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: They've all stopped at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: There's only about one explanation for a thing like this..Got a pin? She reaches under the lapel of the Pastor's jacket, hands a pin to Clayton. He puts it on the counter, then brings the case of his watch near it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pin leaps at the watch-case, drawn magnetically.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: See that? My watch is magnetized. Sylvia's hands come INTO SHOT as she slips off her wrist-watch to try it against the pin.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Everyone starts to test watch cases against bobby- pins, hairpins, exclaiming.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: That's what knocked the phones out, too.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: How could it happen to everybody's watch together?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Over him) Have you got a pocket compass? The Sheriff produces one in a case. Clayton sets it on the counter. They bend to watch the needle.
(Sharply) That needle ain't pointing north!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: It's pointing out to the gully - where that meteor came down. The thin SCREAM OF A SIREN sounds 0.S. Everyone starts for the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting from the entrance of the social hall, as people pile out, Clayton, Sylvia and Pastor Collins with them. The town is completely blacked out. The only visible light is from a police car, using hand siren and red blinker. Its headlights silver the dark streets as it races up.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: How does it happen cars are running?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Automobile ignitions are insulated. Brakes screech. The car pulls over, stops. A COP - middle-aged, solid - tumbles out.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Sheriff! What's goin' on?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: (Hurrying to him) I don't know no more'n you, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (To Sylvia and Pastor Collins, moving away) Excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: (Pointing) Look at the fire out there!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Beyond houses and hilltops, the glow of a fire, four miles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COP and the Sheriff gazing out as Clayton joins  69. 70. 71. 72. them. Everyone staring with them.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: (To Clayton) Let's go see! They get into the car. Sylvia watches it go. SOUND of motor and siren over SCENE. The group breaks up as people run to their cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police car bumps toward us, blinker working. The SIREN DIES.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: CROSS ANGLE. As the Police car comes to a stop, Clayton and the Sheriff hop out downstage, the Cop gets out on the driver's side. Behind the car, bushes are blazing. Above, on the hilltop, the Martian heat-ray has left a line of fire which stretches straight into the night. In its path, some way off, a transmission tower has fallen, partly melted, high-tension wires trailing, still sparking.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Looking toward fallen tower) That explains why the lights went out! The Cop, standing beside the spotlight, looks off.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: (Pointing) What the bejeepers went on here? Look at their cars...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cars belonging to Fiddler and the others are gray, ashy shapes, collapsed. Hardly recognizable except for their tires, which leave a darker residue. Bushes and grass are still burning around.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Jittery, he reaches for the spotlight and snaps it on toward the gully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73a. 74. 75. 76. 77. And look there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REVERSE ANGLE over the men to the meteor in the gully. The beam of the Cop's spotlight sweeps over the smoldering bushes and rough ground, striking the bottom of the meteor and then returning to something on the edge above the gully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff wets his suddenly dry lips, gazing PAST CAMERA. Clayton looks with him.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE ON THE EDGE OF THE GULLY
dialogues.text: Three shallow piles of gray ash, man-shaped, lie on the bare and blackened earth, held in the spotlight.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON, SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Looking PAST CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (To Cop) People in town started to follow us out. (Looking toward gully) Don't let them come anywhere near here. (Suddenly authoritative - loud) Get going!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The hooded shape on its flexible shaft now rears twelve or fifteen feet above the meteor. The cobra- head is turning, zero-ing toward the road. It begins to glitter inside the hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cop is diving into the car in panic.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Kill that spotlight. Turn off your headlights! The cop cuts all the lights, backs around and takes off the way he came, CAMERA PANNING with him.  Tia. 78. 79. 80. 81.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: The SOUND of the SCREAMING of the heat-ray whirls them about as the reddish light glows on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Sharp - to Sheriff) Jump! Get under cover!! They dash off in the direction taken by the car.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: A REVERSE ANGLE, SHOOTING along the road toward the gully. The meteor is concealed behind a knoll. Clayton and the Sheriff, b.g. race down the road to fÂ£.g. and dive into a ditch as the superheated glare of the heat-ray swings from the gully toward them. The SCREAM is ear-splitting in intensity.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The ray SCREAMS over their heads. It holds above the ditch. Throbbing. Its reddish glare blinding.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The car turns incandescent as the ray envelopes it, still going forward. It turns ashy gray. Hits a boulder on the shoulder of the road and breaks up into a spray of ashes.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: A REVERSE ANGLE on them huddled low as the ray cuts off. They whirl about toward the meteor.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: (Wild) What is that gizmo?!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Controlled) I think that - gizmo - is a machine from another planet.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: (Shaken) We better get word to the authorities and -- (Gazing up)  82. 83. 83a. 84. 85. Look!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Beyond the burning grass, another meteor is spurting down the sky, bright and burning green.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Sheriff - you'd better get word to the military. You're going to need them out here!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The hooded shape revolves about, searching. Its snout glitters and glows alternately as it searches for a target. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: MARINE TRUCKS
dialogues.text: a. Main Street, Linda Rosa. No lights. No neon signs. Three trucks smash through the town. Loaded with Marines. b. Low CAMERA - jeeps. A Machine-gun jeep is charging over the crest of a low hill, drop- ping to lower ground. Another follows. Guns and helmeted men are silhouetted against the sky. c. Two personnel trucks rolling fast, parting where dirt roads cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond is a windbreak of eucalyptus trees and a low earth bank. Parked on the side road is a remote- control truck from the KGEB radio station. A few reporters and cameramen are on the black-top road, gazing out over open ground toward the gully. CAMERA favors the KGEB REPORTER - ex-newsman, high- wire and alert, sharkskin suit and Panama hat. He has a portable mike, is interviewing PROFESSOR  86. 87. OGILVY - a youngish, half-bald intellectual. Clayton stands by. Near them is the Sheriff and Marine COLONEL HEFFNER - easy-mannered, tough.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER
dialogues.text: (At mike) ...The area is under control of the Marines from El Toro Base, and the gully is under close observation...And now -- here is Professor Ogilvy from the Canadian Meteor- ological Research Council! (To Prof. Ogilvy - extending mike) Is it true you've had reports about land- ings in other places, Professor?

dialogues.speaker: PROF. OGILVY
dialogues.text: Yes. In Bordeaux, France. Some from Spain. There's supposed to be one down near the Gulf of Taranto, Italy. We're still trying to locate the second meteor that dropped in this vicinity just about midnight.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER
dialogues.text: D'you think they come from Mars?

dialogues.speaker: PROF. OGILVY
dialogues.text: (Deferring) What do you think, Doctor Forrester?

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: KGEB man and his mike f.g., catching the faces of Colonel Heffner, the Sheriff, Prof. Ogilvy, Clayton and reporters who are listening.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: It's possible. At least, it seems certain they're from some other planet than our own.

dialogues.speaker: PROF. OGILVY
dialogues.text: Recently Mars and our earth were in conjunction -- (Adds) -- in line. This could account for the extended radio interference lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cheesy, sleazy store. They sell radios, TV and musical instruments. Big signs in the windows. A  88. console in the doorway. A bunch of bums hanging around, listening.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (Over radio) In fact -- if they are from Mars -- it is possible they first made landings on the moon and used it as an observation post! A bum with an unlighted stub of a cigar takes it out, backs off, looking up at the sky. Others look with him, then at one another.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (Over radio) That makes the old moon appear a lot less friendly, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST BUM
dialogues.text: (Half-whispering) This a gag?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BUM
dialogues.text: (Listening) Shaddap...!

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Suppose they are Martians, Professor. What would they look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING past a group of well-dressed people eating a supper snack from a big coffee table by a picture win- dow. Through this we can see Los Angeles spread out below, neons glowing like jewels. The group is listening attentively to a radio.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (Continuing his questioning) Bigger than us? Smaller?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR OGILVY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Well, as to Martians -- our gravitational pull would weigh them down. Our heavier air would oppress them....

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: But d'you think they'd be breathing creatures like us? What about hearts and blood and all that? A bird-brained blonde moves into SCENE, staring.  89.

dialogues.speaker: PROF. OGILVY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: My field is limited. Doctor Forrester could tell you much more.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: (Over Prof. Ogilvy) Oh, how dull - everybody listening to the radio!

dialogues.speaker: BIG GUY
dialogues.text: (Grabbing her) Qui-et! Siddown!

dialogues.speaker: PROF. OGILVY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: But if they are Martians, and if they do have hearts, they'd almost certainly beat at a slower rate. Their veins might be distended...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: San Francisco, with the Golden Gate Bridge and City behind. A BOY driving, smooching a GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (Over car radio) Their senses could be quite different from ours, of course. They may, for instance, be able to smell colors. There is precedent in our own evolution to make it possible that they have more than one brain... The boy reaches to cut off the radio - he wants to smooch. The girl stops him. He is annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You mean two? Three? More, maybe?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It's only speculation.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Think of that, folks! Now, Doctor Forrester - what about these meteor machines?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: They're probably controlled by jets after they enter our atmosphere... And navigated by some form of gyroscope mechanism.  90. 91. 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA is CLOSE on a picture of a battleship, then PULLS BACK revealing a poster: SAN DIEGO ARENA - BOXING. The SHOT WIDENS to show local fishermen, a couple of Navy sailors, a few girls - grouped by a small portable radio on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Is it true that all the phones went out and everybody's watch stopped around here?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: That was, I imagine, the effect from some electro-magnetic force in the heat-ray they used.

dialogues.speaker: T-CROSSING
dialogues.text: The KGEB Reporter, Clayton, Prof. Ogilvy, Colonel Heffner. Newspaper men have moved closer, listening.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB. REPORTER
dialogues.text: Can you tell us anything about this plane that's coming over, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL HEFFNER
dialogues.text: It'll drop a flare -- that's the only way we dare put a light on them. Then Air Force cameramen will get pictures.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER
dialogues.text: That was Marine Colonel Ralph Heffner... (In a confidential tone) There's been a lot of mysterious activity around the machine. Lights and dust, as if they are digging themselves out. (Shimmering light hits his face) There it comes again!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: A shuddering, blue-green light shows in the distance, tinting nearby hills.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: If this keeps up, it'll be a guide for the plane when it comes over.  93. 94. 95. 96.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHES
dialogues.text: Groups dispersed under cover, relaxed but alert, all watching the gully. a. Two mortar teams in a dry riverbed. b. Marine lieutenant and a sergeant with binocu- lars, behind a low revetment. c. Machine-gun unit in a foxhole. d. Infantrymen, alert and watchful.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: KGEB Reporter f.g., Clayton, Colonel Heffner and Sheriff just beyond him. Reporters and cameramen line out along the road, waiting. The SOUND of the plane OVERSCENE. Its motor cuts off and on again.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER
dialogues.text: (In a sharp whisper) Is that the plane now?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL HEFFNER
dialogues.text: (Looking up, quietly) Yes! He's signalling.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER
dialogues.text: (Into mike) The pilot has just blipped his motor. That means he's dropped the flare. He's flying high, and it'll take a few seconds to come down. When it does burst, we shall be the first men on earth to get a real look at these invaders from space - whoever they are! And there's the flare!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The flare throws a cone of high-visibility light. The Martian meteor has been cleared of dirt, stripped of its oxydized shell. It is an oblong cylinder. from the center of it, the hooded shape on the flex- ible shaft has been pushed high, like & guarding sentinel.
The hooded shape rears back on its flexible shaft, angling up. The snout glitters, begins to glow, brilliant, reddish. Then the heat-ray SCREAMS as it lashes up into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Clayton, the KGEB reporter and other watching the sky tensely. The reporter has stopped gabbing, his microphone forgotten. The blue-white glare of the flare, mingled with the reddish glow of the heat- ray, alternate in flickers over SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER
dialogues.text: (Suddenly remembering mike) They're after the plane with their rays!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The SCREAMING heat-ray lashes across the sky. Writhing, seeking its target. It licks the flare into oblivion, then whips downward toward the ears and swings at us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody dives for cover. The glare of the ray turns everything fiery red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Colonel and the KGEB reporter flatten out to- gether behind the low earth bank. Burning twigs and leaves fall about them. Clayton cranes to look out with the Colonel. The reporter yaks into his mike.

dialogues.speaker: KGEB REPORTER
dialogues.text: Well, here we are in --- (Pulls at charred end of mike cable - looks out) Hey! They cut me off. They got my truck!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: It looks like they're going to come out of that gully pretty soon ...! We'd better build a shelter and be ready when they do.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: You're going to need plenty of reinforcements.  102. 103. 104.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: We'll get âem. (Calling off) Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troops and armament racing into the Linda Rosa district: Trucks -- tanks -- weapons carriers -- half-tracks jeeps -- rocket launchers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge truck loaded with troops thunders past CAMERA. Its passing uncovers the hastily erected sandbag revet- ment for the command post. Nearby is an ambulance, a Red Cross canteen truck with two women in uniform working, several jeeps waiting with motors running. Two jeeps start away in different directions. A jeep rolls into SCENE, laying wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sylvia is at the rear corner of the revetment, holding a tray of coffee mugs and doughnuts. She pauses to watch more vehicles move past. She has changed out of her dance frock into a tailored dress. She has a Red Cross armband. CAMERA PICKS UP Clayton coming from within the revetment inclosure.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Pausing beside Sylvia) The troops are certainly moving in here!

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Didn't you have something to do with this? I know you sent word to the Sixth Army Command!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Taking coffee tray - turning back with it) I just told them the local situation. Colonel Heffner's in full charge now.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Pausing - looking around) You never know where you're going to wind up when you go to a square dance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An opening in the sandbag breastwork for observation high in the forward end. Storm lanterns provide light. A huge tarpaulin is stretched over the revet- ment as a roof and pulled down to cover the opening, which overlooks the Martians in the gully beyond. A field telephone switchboard and field telegraph have been set up. On some boxes is an enlarged con- tour map of the immediate territory, showing Linda Rosa, surrounding roads, the site of the Martian pit. A LIEUTENANT and a sergeant work on this map, placing units as they report in position. A CAPTAIN is on the phone. constantly pass messages. telegraph key. All are in atmosphere is alive, action of dispatch bearers tense. Communications men at other phones A sergeant operates a full battle dress. The There is constant b.g. coming and going. As Sylvia and Clayton come the Colonel is brief- ing officers at the map. in,

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Locate your observation post on this hill. Position your recoilless 75's back here - Caroon Canyon. (To another officer) I want your battery here. You may find at daylight that you're too exposed -- so keep your prime movers ready to pull you out fast. (Smiling) But you'll get first crack at âem.

dialogues.speaker: A CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: That'll suit me! That all, sir?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Yes. (As the lieutenant hands a phone) Report when you're set up. Sylvia passes around coffee and doughnuts. Clayton takes two mugs, bringing one across to the Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (At phone) Half-tracks?...Okay. Get in back of hill Thuh-ree. Follow up from there if it's a moving target... Roger! He takes coffee from Clayton with one hand and a Signal Corps message with the other.
(To Clayton) They've located that second meteor. (Passing message to Lieutenant) Mark it up.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE MAP
dialogues.text: As Pastor Collins comes in, wearing a Civil Defense armband. The Sheriff follows, pausing to reach for doughnuts and coffee. The lieutenant marks another Martian pit about five miles west, toward Whittier. He draws a line linking it with the Martians in the gully.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (To Clayton, pointing to map) There's one - there's the other, and we're right between them!

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: (Moving in) So is the town, I notice!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: I warned you Civil Defense people to be ready if you have to evacuate.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: I just came to tell you - everyone has been alerted. The Colonel's glance is caught by something o.s. He stiffens to attention. GENERAL MANN'S VOICE (o.s.) As you were...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING toward the rear as GENERAL MANN comes in -- fiftyish, clipped mustache, wearing neat khaki. Carries field glasses. His aide, a young MAJOR, follows him.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (Moving to meet him) General Mann -- I was told to expect you, sir. I'm Colonel Heffner.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: (Smiling briefly) I'm here to make up a report, not to interfere with the operations you've  107. set up. You're still in command. (Suddenly - warmly) Clayton Forrester! (Shaking hands) I haven't seen you since Oak Ridge.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Good to see you, General. (Introducing) This is Pastor Collins, director of Civil Defense. Sheriff Bogany, head of the local forces ... Miss Van Buren.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Would you like some coffee, General?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: Thank you. She starts out as his aide hands him some messages.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (To Pastor) General Mann's in charge of Intel- ligence for the Pacific area.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Favoring General Mann as he turns to scan the map, continuing to glance at the messages. The lieutenant is marking up more positions.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: That's their position? (Grimly amused) You've certainly got them surrounded. (And then) I suppose they've neutralized all communications here.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Not all. Radio is out. But our field phones are okay so far.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: And they'll go out the minute there's another ray. (Reading) A cylinder reported down by Huntington Beach. That's a job for the Navy.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Do you have any news from abroad? CAMERA ANGLES to favor him as he glances at messages, sorting them, handing some to his aide.  GENERAL MANN (Cont'd) They're coming down all over. South America - Santiago has two cylinders. They're outside London. And they're in Naples. (Going on) We've got them between here and Fesno. Outside Sacramento. Two on Long Island...

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Are they just coming down at random?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: No, they're working to some kind of a plan. (After a moment) But here's the most dangerous thing... Once they begin to move -- no more news comes out of that area!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING past the General. Everyone is listening, fascinated. The communications men have stopped work. The morse key keeps repeating a call.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: We've been getting reports of destruction, massacre ... Here's an instance! (reading a message) "Town of St. Julien, south of Bordeaux, wiped out by ray of undetermined nature. Local reports say nothing remains.' (Looks around) Nothing remains! What d'you make of that?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: We'll have to see what they do here.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: A lot of our newest weapons are in here. Washington wants to be sure we stop them.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (Confident - smiling) We will, sir!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: From the data - and from that picture the Air Force took earlier tonight (Thumbing toward the gully) what we've got in the gully out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: there is a guide ship. One lands Others follow later. (To Clayton) They appear to clear an area, then drop in groups of threes, joined magnetically. Is that possible?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Weyly) If they do it, it is. Sylvia brings coffee. The General takes it automatically.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: My orders are not to go into action unless they make a move out of there.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: That's because we want a chance to observe them. (Gesturing to gully) This is the only place we've had time to surround them with sufficient force to contain them. What happens here will be a guide to all other operations. The minute action begins and a pattern of defense develops, I'll get my report to Washington. (Glances at map) You've deployed your forces well.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. If they start anything, we can blast them right off the earth!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: (Checks watch, sips coffee) They'll probably move at dawn.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Silence. No movement anywhere. We see the burned grass and blackened earth. The little gray ash-heaps are still there. In the gully are dim, shining shapes. Beyond the hills the sky is lightening. As the sun comes up, one of the shining shapes begins to rise. There is a SOUND of CRACKLING, HIGH-FREQUENCY ELECTRIC SPARKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA is on an infantry lieutenant and a sergeant.  113. 114. 115. Their foxhole is camouflaged with burned grass and bushes.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: (At field phone) There's something moving in the gully -- something's coming out!

dialogues.speaker: FLASHES
dialogues.text: Men have been resting, dozing, waiting for dawn. A signal reaches them. a. Recoilless 75 men running to positions. b. Crew racing to half-track rocket-launcher. c. Machine-gunners readying for action. da. Bazooka team alerting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamps and candles being hurriedly extinguished. The tarpaulin is yanked from the observation opening. Everyone cranes to get a glimpse of the gully.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Burned-over ground runs straight to the gully, with blackened scrub trees and bushes at either side. Something is visible in the gully. Shining. Moving.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Now, for the first time, we see a Martian machine clearly. A metal shape is rising. The SOUND of high- frequency sparks increases. It is a built-up section of the cylinder. Domed in the center. Three vibrant beams are projected like rods from below - stiff, joint- less, incandescent. Effortlessly, the body of the machine rises on the pulsating beams to a height of thirty feet in the air, and hovers motionless. Then a hooded shape extends above the body on a flexible shaft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring Clayton, Pastor Collins, General Mann and the Colonel. All crowded to the opening in the sandbags. The General and the Colonel use field glasses.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: (Softly - handing his glasses to Clayton) Look at it, will you?

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: (Awed - half to himself) Beings from another world The Colonel signs to the Captain, who backs to the field telephone switchboard.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (Quietly) Stand by to fire.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: (Into phone - repeating) All command posts stand by to fire.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: (Suddenly realizing - protesting) Colonel - shooting's no good!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: It's always been a good persuader.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: Couldn't you try to communicate with them first - and shoot later if you have to? The Colonel glances, then ignores him, using his glasses. The uniformed men are all tense, watching the gully, waiting for the order. Clayton is gazing out with the Sheriff. Pastor Collins moves uncertainly toward the open rear of the revetment. Sylvia sees him, starts after him. CAPTAIN'S VOICE (0.s.) All command posts - target as indicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pastor Collins comes out, stands staring toward the gully. Sylvia joins him. Behind them we glimpse the tension of the men inside.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: (Looking o.s.) I think we should try to make them understand we mean them no harm. Sylvia looks at him, not sure of what he means.  117. COLONEL'S VOICE (0.s.) (Quietly - from inside) There's another machine coming out.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The Martian machines. The first machine is now catching the early sunbeams. Turning golden, glis- tening. In the shadows another machine is rising from the gully. It, also, is armed with a hooded shape.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA AND PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: Both gazing toward the gully.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: (Meditative) They are living creatures out there.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: But they're not human! Dr. Forrester says they're some kind of an advanced civilization --

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: (Cutting in, smiling) If they're more advanced than us, they should be nearer the Creator for that reason!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (Tensely, from inside) Attention all batteries! Prepare for volley fire! Repeat -- prepare for volley fire!

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: (Meditative again) No real attempt has been made to communicate with them, you know... Sylvia looks at him uneasily. She takes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Let's go back inside, Uncle Matthew.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: (Shakes head, smiling) I've done about all I can do here. You go back in. (Low - turning her toward the inside) Sylvia - I like that Doctor Forrester. (Hand to her cheek)  119. 120. 121. 124. 125. 126. He's a good man. Sylvia presses his hand, smiling. As she leaves him, the CAMERA PANS with her, losing Pastor Collins momentarily.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: Looking in the direction of the gully, thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHES
dialogues.text: a. Grouped bazookas bearing on the target. b. Tanks waiting orders, at the ready. c. Rocket launcher, loaded and ready.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The Martian machine in f.g. is motionless. The second one has paused half out of the gully. Its hooded arm swings around on its shaft, as if under test.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: Eyes serene. Smiles a little. Moves forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sound except the telegraph key repeating a signal over and over. No movement save for Sylvia, f.g., refilling coffee cups. General Mann, the Colonel, Clayton and the Sheriff crouched by the opening.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (Suddenly) Who's that?!

dialogues.speaker: GROUP AT WINDOW
dialogues.text: They stare out, disbelieving.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: She whirls, starts toward the opening.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: SHOOTING over the group at the opening to the VISTA outside the revetment. In b.g. Pastor Collins is walking away from the revetment, a solitary figure moving over the burned-off earth. The Martian machines beyond him are motionless, as if awaiting him.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (Choked voice) What's he think he's doing?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Calling) Uncle! (Half screaming) Uncle Matthew! ! She whirls to go after him. General Mann catches her arm.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: Too late now -- he's too far away.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Lunges - appealing) Stop him!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Holding her - looking out) It's seen him.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: It begins slowly to sink down as its glittering beam- legs pulsate and grow shorter.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BURNED-OFF FIELD
dialogues.text: Pastor Collins brings out a cross, gazing ahead, reciting the Twenty-third Psalm.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: (Softly) Though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: SHOOTING past the first Martian machine, still sinking down. The second machine has risen higher in the gully.  131. 132. 133. 135.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BURNED-OFF FIELD
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Pastor Collins, walking past more debris.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: (Whispering) Thou anointest my head with oil. My cup runneth over

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring Sylvia and Clayton. All are crowded to the opening. Sylvia is petrified with horror.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BURNED-OFF FIELD
dialogues.text: Pastor Collins moves ahead, eyes fixed on the machines. He won't permit himself to be afraid.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR COLLINS
dialogues.text: And I will dwell ... in the house of the Lord .. forever. He lifts the cross to shoulder height as CAMERA HOLDS and PANS him on. PASTOR COLLINS (Cont'd) Amen. (Murmuring) May the grace of the Father and of the Son Beyond him we now see the Martian machine.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Favoring the first machine, filling the SCREEN. Squat- ting on its incandescent beam-legs, the hooded shaft tilted forward. There is a moment -- then a magenta- tinted heat-ray SCREAMS from it.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: She SCREAMS, but her voice is drowned in the unearthly SOUND of the Martian machine. We know, without seeing, what has happened to the Pastor.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: VIEWPOINT from the command post revetment. The first machine rises swiftly to full height, gliding forward.  141. 142. The second clears the gully. The top of a third machine appears.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The base of the Martian machine's locomotor beam-leg. Featuring, in f.g., the Pastor's cross, partly melted. The glittering foot of the beam moves into SCENE, leaving behind it molten rock and smoke. As it passes, the intense heat it gives off acts like a blowtorch on the terrain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING from outside the observation opening. Sylvia is CLOSE in f.g., horrified, unbelieving, supported by Clayton. The Colonel whirls toward the switchboard.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Let 'em have it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big guns of the tanks slam shells toward the gully.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Shells burst close to the Martian machine. Instantly a beam -- different from the heat-ray -- strikes out with a vicious, high-pitched DRUMMING SOUND. The beam is electric-blue with a greenish tinge. Edges soft, powdery. Fast, projectile-like discharges race down its core, like a succession of balls, a deeper blue- green. Beam and impulses are transparent.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The beam hits a tank. The tank changes color instan- taneously. It turns bone yellow, then thins into an oyster-white skeleton shape that is an echo of death itself. The beam cuts off and the tank dissolves into fine dust, the color of the beam, and blows away on the breeze. Making pallid streamers in the early morning light.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: SHOOTING IN on the men - staring, transfixed. The General lowers his glasses, looks at Clayton in stupe- faction, then uses the glasses again.  143. 144.

dialogues.speaker: INSERTS OF MUZZLES
dialogues.text: CLOSE on the muzzles. Individual SOUND blasting. a. Rocket-launcher muzzles as rockets fly. b. Machine-gun muzzles shuddering. c. Anti-tank gun muzzles explode and recoil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The initial phase between man's weapons and the Martian machines. The first Martian is out of the gully on the burned-off field. The second is just clear of the gully. The third has started to follow. a. Special Effect - Full Shot - Gully. Increasing shell and rocket fire bursting viciously about the Martians. Short, blue jets are flashing out around the turret heads of the machines. These merge to form an impalpable, electro- magnetic envelope which drops all around to the ground. b. Special Effect - Close Shot - First Machine. Rays SCREAM from it, lashing in every direction. c. Recoilless 75's - Close Shot. Muzzles Flash. d. Rocket-launcher - Close Shot. In rapid suc- cession, rockets roar toward the Martians. e. Tank - Med. Shot. It's gun bucks violently slamming an armor-piercing shell at the Mar- tians. f. Machine-gun Nest - Close Shot. 50 cal. machine- gun chatters furiously, spitting a stream of tracer shells. g. Bazookas - Close Shot. In a sharp volley, a group of bazookas let go with HE charges. h. Mortars - Close Shot. In rapid succession, Marines drop Napalm charges into the big muz- zles of the mortars. Instantly the charges fly high in the air in the direction of the enemy. in Special Effect - Martian Machines. Projectiles burst against their almost invisible protective envelopes. Others ricochet off, exploding harm- lessly in the air beyond. Napalm charges burst around them, obscuring the machines in huge

balls of searing, orange fire and black smoke. i. Special Effect - First Machine - Close Shot. The flame of the Napalm clears. The machine is undamaged. Rays slash from it, SCREAMING. k. Special Effect - Second & Third Machines - Close Shot. Flames and smoke clear. They lash rays in every direction. 1. Special Effect - Rocket-launcher - Close Shot. Hit by a heat-ray. The launcher and crew glow white hot. Become a pile of ashes. m. Special Effect - First Machine - Close Shot. DRUMMING horribly, the blue-green disintegrating beam darts forth. n. Special Effect - Mortars - Med. Close Shot. Hit by the skeletonizing beam. They literally disintegrate - cease to exist. Men and machines become a vapor of blue-green dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton, Sylvia and others duck below the shelter of the sandbags as a heat-ray HOWLS close past the com- mand post. CAMERA MOVES IN on Clayton and General Mann, shouting above the uproar.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: (Fast, looking out) What's that skeleton beam they're using?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: It must neutralize mesons somehow. They're the atomic glue that holds matter together. (Grimly) Cut across their lines of magnetic force and any object will simply cease to exist.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The destruction of man's weapons by the Martians, and the beginning of man's retreat. a. Special Effect - Ext. Gully & Command Post Revetment - Full Shot. A COMPOSITE SHOT of the entire battle. One Martian machine on a hill slope. The two others below. Rays and beams lashing out. Shells and rockets and Napalm exploding about them. Tanks scuttling about.  146. 147. 148. Rays hit them. Machine-gunners and troops abandon their stations, leaving their weapons. Half-tracks, trucks, weapons-carriers, jeeps pull out. Pandemonium. b. Special Effect - Martian Machines - Med. Shot. smoke and fire clearing. Explosions about them diminish. They redouble the activity of their rays and beams. c. Special Effect - Battlefield - Med. Full Shot. Gray ash on a blackened road - the residue of tanks. Men, jeeps, equipment flee past, es- caping. Rays and beams reach after them. d. Ext. Hillside - Med. Close Shot. Infantrymen crash through burning bushes in headlong re- treat, looking back in panic. e. Special Effect - Martian Machine - Close Shot. On skyline. Moving forward. Rays SCREAMING, beams DRUMMING. No counter fire from our forces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parked jeeps, General Mann's car, a few Marines, the Red Cross truck. The heat-ray slashes through them, hits the revetment and swings away. Men fall in ashes, jeeps glow and burn, the Red Cross truck and General Mann's car are singed and blazing. The huge tarp stretched over the revetment blazes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inclosure is a madhouse - men trying to extinguish burning switchboards - the lieutenant gathering up the scorched maps - the captain shouting uselessly into the field phone - Clayton up by the opening using the field glasses, Sylvia and the Sheriff crouched near him. General Mann and his aide rush out.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: (At the opening) There's a Martian machine headed straight for us!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (Shouting to Captain) Order all command posts - everything pull back north of Highway Sixty tunnel bunker!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
