dialogues.text: Moving along the burned-off swathe from the gully, rays slashing.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (At observation opening - yelling) They're going to roll right through here. Sheriff - get into Linda Rosa. Tell Civil Defense - evacuate everybody! Clayton, at the opening, watches the approaching machines, absorbed by them. A heat-ray slashes near, casting its ruddy glare. Shreds of the burning tar- paulin fall. Sylvia grabs him, pulling him down.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Doctor Forrester - get out of here! He literally jerks Clayton and Sylvia to their feet, shoving them toward the rear. COLONEL (Cont'd) Everybody out! The Air Force'll take care of these babies now! (Runs toward CAMERA) Everybody out --- Everybody ---- He is in EXTREME CLOSEUP, shouting. The red heat-ray seems to envelope him in a blaze of color, SCREAMING. Suddenly the SCREEN explodes into deadly blue-green - the disintegrating beam! The Colonel's shout is frozen on his lips. The skeletal structure of his head glows incandescent -- greenish-white -- through the flesh of his face. In an instant he vanishes into a shred of blue-green vapor which swirls and is lost in the ruddy flames of the ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge formation of fighter bombers flashes across the sky, the chorus of their jets pulsating like thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A weapons carrier clatters past at breakneck speed. Men from mixed units jump from behind scrub trees,  152. 153. 154. 155. running. A crowded jeep flashes past as Clayton and Sylvia appear. The two run after the men. Clayton pulls her to a stop, looks o.s., then runs across the road with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Piper Cub - battery observation plane - is just taking off. Another is on the ground, no one near it. Clayton and Sylvia enter, running. Beyond one wing of the machine we see smoke, explosions and rays and beams ripping against the sky.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: We can't go into town - everybody's getting out of there! (Steering her toward plane) I'll fly you over to Pasadena.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Can you handle one of these?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Sure...get in! He shoves Sylvia up into the plane and climbs in at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Piper Cub in flight, hedge-hopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING PAST Clayton to Sylvia. The tops of utility poles and trees skim past, almost at their level. The plane wobbles. Clayton is unconcerned.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Hanging on) You'll hit something! Can't you go higher?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Looking up) No. The air's going to be full of Jets in a minute...And there they are!
Jet fighter-bombers in formation, colorful against the sky, peeling off to dive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton looking o.s. as he banks sharply. Sylvia looking after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jet fighter-bombers diving, firing, launching rockets, dropping bombs. SOUNDS of explosions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The piper cub porpoising over the treetops, banking and turning.

dialogues.speaker: WRECK OF PIPER CUB
dialogues.text: a. Int. Piper Cub - Close Shot (Process) . Clayton looking up. Sylvia turns and looks ahead, SCREAMS. b. Special Effect - Piper Cub - Full Shot. SHOOTING AHEAD. It rises over a low hilltop - flying directly toward a Martian machine on the flat fields beyond. Plane banks sharply to change course. c. Special Effect - Piper Cub - Med. Shot. The wing snags a tree. The plane cart- wheels toward the ground.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The Cub lands on one wheel, bounces, goes into a ground loop, a slashing skid and stops, tilted on a torn wing. Propeller shattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton half-falls out of the wrecked plane, looking o.s., as he helps Sylvia. She looks with him, gasps. They run and dive into an irrigation ditch, CAMERA FOLLOWING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 163a. 164. SHOOTING over the torn wing of the Piper Cup among the tangled bean plants. Across the field is a low, wooded hill. Coming into sight at the foot of the hill is the Martian machine, its cobra-like weapon turning on its shaft, swinging toward the plane.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Ducked low, taut, terrified. He sneaks a look over the edge, then flings himself down with Sylvia again. There is the SOUND of the horrible DRUMMING of the disintegrating beam, which quickly flickers out, mark- ing the destruction of the Piper Cub. Their faces are lit blue-green. Then, down into the ditch, the eerie vapor of unglued atom flows, incandescent, swirling in the breeze. Clayton and Sylvia begin to stir. The CRACKLING of HIGH FREQUENCY ELECTRICITY from the machine's loco- motor mechanism grows louder - it's coming for them! Clayton grabs Sylvia, half-dragging, half-carrying her back along the ditch. He pushes her behind a pile of broken irrigation pipe, falls across her. The CRACKLING swells to a ROAR of SPARKS. Where they had just lain, the glittering, flickering base of a beam-leg dips down into the ditch, moves across and up the other bank, leaving a smoking path of fused rock and debris.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Smoke swirling about them. Heads thrust into the dirt. Frozen with terror. Faces crushed together. The machine's ROAR diminishes. They begin to breathe again. The tension of Clayton's grip on Sylvia's shoulders lessens. The suspended functions of her mind resume. Her eyes turn to him. He looks at her. Shock overwhelms her. She faints. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA is on a CORNER NEWSSTAND. Tip-sheets and papers are clipped around the front, sides and to a wire between uprights. Headlines: MEN FROM MARS - Europe Cities Blasted - KILLER RAYS; MARS MACHINES IN CALIFORNIA - Fighting Near L.A. - U.S. INVADED - MARTIAN THREAT. A little crowd on the sidewalk reads papers avidly. Cars stop at the curb to buy others. An elderly woman sits behind the newsstand, knitting, hawking her sensations.  165. 167.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: (Thin - piping) All about the Martian Invasion - They're in New York and Miami - Fighting outside Los Angeles - All about it! - Radio black- out - Killers from Mars - World-wide Crisis - United States invaded - all about the Martians! (Sells a paper) Thank you, mister. The SOUND of approaching sirens comes over SCENE. She and her customers look o.s. EXT. STREET - (Location) Traffic is slowing, stopping. The SOUND of massed sirens comes to a peak. Two motorcycle cops race past, blinkers working. Four more follow. Then comes General Mann's dirty, fire-blackened car. CAMERA PANS the car, going fast, then ANGLES UP the front of the stately Federal Building.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE
dialogues.text: Five desks. Walls covered with maps and thumb-tacked notices. The doors of three private offices across from the entrance. The place is crowded with Army, Navy, Marine and Air Force personnel, police of- ficials, CD directors, reporters, photographers. Two cops shoulder in from the corridor by a door marked: ARMED FORCES - Public Information Office - Entrance. General Mann follows with his aide. Reporters and cameramen crowd around the unshaven, grimy General, impeding him on his way toward a private office out- side which sits a WAC secretary. Naval and military men come to attention, then press toward him. The General looks past them all, calling to CD directors and civic authorities.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: (Beckoning) You're the gentlemen I asked to come here. (To his aide) Get Washington. The aide pushes ahead while flashbulbs blink and repor-  ters surround the General. He keeps moving. A FAT REPORTER - thin-nosed, sweating - tries to buttonhole him.

dialogues.speaker: FAT REPORTER
dialogues.text: General Mann, what d'you think of this situation --

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: Sorry. I've no time!

dialogues.speaker: FAT REPORTER
dialogues.text: (Wily, fast) Is it your opinion the Army can hold âem?

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CHIEF
dialogues.text: (Moving in, sharp) All right, boys - let it go!

dialogues.speaker: SECOND REPORTER
dialogues.text: (Jumping in, over him) You had guns and equipment going out there all night! Weren't they enough to --

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: (Tired, exasperated) I said I've no time!

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CHIEF
dialogues.text: C'mon, now - break it up! During this, General Mann has pushed to the door of the private office. With a concerted effort, the General and the civic officials push inside. The door closes. A big Marine bars further entry. CAMERA HOLDS on the reporters and photographers.

dialogues.speaker: FAT REPORTER
dialogues.text: The way he's hedging, maybe the Army didn't hold âem! (Significant) Because from the news that's coming through, nobody's stopped âem yet! (Looking toward door) We'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It belongs to the Chief of Army Information. General Mann's aide is talking into a phone in b.g. The General faces the civilian group which includes police and fire chiefs, Pacific Electric and other trans- portation officials, Air Raid wardens, Red Cross.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: Who's the General Director for Civil Defense?

dialogues.speaker: C.D. DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Here, sir. We're all ready for action!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: I want to know if the city must be evacuated...?

dialogues.speaker: C.D. DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: (Smiling) Lots of people got scared and moved out as it is!

dialogues.speaker: P.E. OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: We're holding emergency cars and buses ready in the yard, sir!

dialogues.speaker: RED CROSS LEADER
dialogues.text: Red Cross is standing by.

dialogues.speaker: C.D. DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: I believe, sir, I can speak for everyone. We've got the whole city on the ready!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: That's what I wanted! For your in- formation - they're twenty-five or thirty miles outside Los Angeles. They're not down in force yet, but that can happen any minute. We've got a developing situation. It'll come to a crisis if they move into the metropolitan area and --

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: (Cutting in, quick) Washington on the wire, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: (Taking phone, turning away) General Mann...

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: listening at phone, keyed-up.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MAN
dialogues.text: (After a pause, low, fast) I'd say our effective losses were nearly sixty percent men and ninety percent materiel! (Grimly) The new delta-wing jets went in, but  not one of them came out. I watched high-level bombers drop everything they carried. They were knocked out of the sky and the bombs did nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: straining to catch what he is saying, glancing at one another, alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Nothing was effective against them!... Yes, they have some sort of electronic umbrella. It's quite impenetrable. And Doctor Forrester believes they generate atomic force without the heavy screening we use -- That's where they get the power for their rays!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Mann at phone, his aide in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: very well, sir. (Hanging up - to aide) Call Victorville. Tell them I want the fastest plane they've got! SHOT WIDENS as he turns to the nearby group. GENERAL MANN (Cont'd) You'll get all further instructions from Sixth Army Command. (To Police Chief) Now I'll make a statement to those reporters. The Police Chief opens the door. Hubbub comes from the outside as reporters and photographers crowd in. The civic authorities leave.

dialogues.speaker: FAT REPORTER
dialogues.text: (Barging forward) General, we heard Doctor Clayton Forrester was out there with you. What's he think about this?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: Ask him. He's back at Pacific-Tech.

dialogues.speaker: FAT REPORTER
dialogues.text: No, he's not! We tried to get him. He hasn't shown up there.  172a. 172b. 172c. 172d.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Peaceful. Crickets chirruping. A mocking-bird SOUND- ING off. Low ground mist. Out of the distance comes the MUTTER of gunfire and remote EXPLOSIONS. CAMERA SHOOTING across the edge of the dry irriga- tion ditch toward the farmhouse in the middle dis- tance. A farm cat appears over the edge of the ditch, carrying something in its mouth. It hurries down into the ditch, CAMERA PANNING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton is sitting alongside Sylvia who is stretched out asleep. Clayton's jacket is covering her. His attention has been attracted by the cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat stops in the bottom of the ditch and puts her burden down on some grass. It is a tiny puppy. She lies down. It snuggles to her, whining weakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles a little wryly, looks down toward Sylvia. CAMERA PANS to CLOSEUP of Sylvia. She is breathing softly, regularly.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: He bends over, looking at her for a long moment, then his hand touches her shoulder, shaking it to waken her.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Softly) Wake up.... Her eyes open, close, then open again. CLAYTON (Cont'd) (Gently) Let's get moving, huh? She doesn't move, only looks at him. CLAYTON (Cont'd)  173. (Concealing his anxiety - smiling) Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Still half-awake) I never noticed before - that's a cowboy tie....

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I bought it for the square dance. I thought I ought to wear some- thing Western. She laughs dreamily, looking up at him. Her smile goes suddenly. She glances out over the edge of the ditch.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Is that... machine...?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: It's gone now.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Southwest of Corona, somewhere. There must have been another cylinder down here. They've been through this whole area and cleared everybody out. (Peering from the ditch) There's a farmhouse. Let's see if we can find something to eat...! As they prepare to leave,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a skillet loaded with bacon and eggs. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS. The kitchen is not modern. Old gas refrigerator. High-oven stove, its flaming gas-jets make an eerie glow. Coffee percolates. Sylvia has tidied her hair, renewed her make-up. Clayton is taking a jug of orange juice from the refrigerator. He uses it to indicate the farmhouse as he glances around.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: We're doing all right. He puts it on the table, which he has set, then looks  warily out the window. He goes to the stove as Sylvia begins dishing up. She is pensive. They keep their voices down.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I almost forget when I ate last. (Genuine) It looks so good.... You know, mostly I get my meals in coffee shops and restaurants.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Astonished) Don't you live at home?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: No, on the campus. I haven't any family.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I come from a big one. Nine of us. All in Minnesota, except me.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I have no close folks. My parents died when I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON AND SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Shooting across the table to the stove. Sylvia comes toward CAMERA, bringing bacon and eggs. He follows with the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: A big family must be fun...I imagine it makes you feel you belong to something.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: It does...Maybe that's why I feel kind of lost right now.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Reassuring, pouring coffee) We'll get safely out of here, don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Pouring orange juice) But they seem to murder everything that moves...!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: If they're mortal, they must have mortal weaknesses. They'll be stopped -- somehow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They begin to eat.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I've been as close to them as anyone. But not close enough for real observation...

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Over him - not listening) I feel like I did one time when I was small. (Not sorry for herself, merely telling him) Awful scared and lonesome...I'd wandered off - I've forgotten why - but the family and whole crowds of neighbors were hunting for me. (And then) They found me in a church. I was afraid to go in any place else.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Half smiling at the memory.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I stayed right by the door - praying for the one who loved me best to come and find me. (And then) It was Uncle Matthew who found me.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Quietly) I liked him.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TABLE
dialogues.text: Sylvia touches away a tear, keeps her voice con- trolled.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: He liked you ... I could bawl my head off!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: But you're not going to. You're not the kind. (Encouraging, gentle) You're tired, anyway. You've been up all night. You cracked up in a plane. Slept in a ditch. But you  178. want to know something? (Removing glasses looking, smiling) It doesn't show on you at all. As she smiles, holding his gaze, a greenish glow begins to spread through the kitchen. Clayton rises, startled. The light becomes a glare that limns everything sharply - emerald and black. A smashing and roaring SOUNDS outside, approaching like an avalanche. Clayton grabs Sylvia as the house shakes. Part of the ceiling crashes down. The floor rocks under them. They fall, Clayton shielding sylvia, as the walls smash in.

dialogues.speaker: MULTIPLE METEOR
dialogues.text: A multiple meteor has fallen. Through the ground mist we see that one cylinder has gouged up earth and is hitting the farmhouse in f.g. Two other cylinders land in the far distance and are obscured in the mist. All movement ends. Silence follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a broken pipe, gushing water. Sylvia's hand comes into SCENE, soaking a cloth. CAMERA PANS as she draws the cloth away. Clayton is sprawled near the living room doorway, hunched, holding his head. She crouches by him - shaken, anxious - pressing the cloth against his temple. He sits up slowly, holding the cloth against his head, then pressing it over his face and eyes. He is hurt. Finally, he drags the cloth down his face and sucks in his breath. She holds him while his brain steadies.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: How long was I out?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Small, whispering) Hours. I've been so scared..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to get up. She holds him down. SYLVIA (Cont'd) (Whispering) They're right outside! Several of them came down together! Clayton is immediately alert. He rises quietly, CAMERA PANS as he tiptoes to the wall and peers out  185. a vertical break.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Clayton's VIEWPOINT. Everything is seen through or above low ground mist. In b.g. is fencing, trees, sheds. Visible above the mist is a Martian machine, gliding slowly. It stops. CLOSE in f.g., is part of a glit- tering leg that rises to the underside of another machine standing sentinel, straddling the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton's eyes reflect his excitement. He leaves the opening, looks up, starts quickly toward the living room.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Whispering) There's a machine standing right over us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attic has been crushed down in a mess of beams and plaster. The roof has spilled over at one side. Clayton reaches up, pulling at beams and plaster, trying to get a better look. He peers out through an opening to the farmyard again. Sylvia, by the door to the patio, regards him fearfully.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Clayton's VIEWPOINT from the living room. The Martian machine in b.g. is now slowly submerging into the mist. From this vantage point, a third machine is now vis- ible, still on the ground in the farmyard. Now this machine begins to rise on its glowing beam-legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton is peering through the opening in b.g. Sylvia, f.g., standing beside the broken door to the outside patio, turns and looks out. She suppresses a scream, starting away. CAMERA MOVES IN fast, SHOOT- ING past her to the EXTERIOR. The patio is blocked with debris, fallen fuchsias, potted cacti in bloom. A form is just disappearing beyond the debris. Smooth, reddish, indefinite.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Clayton jumps to her side.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Something moved outside! Clayton brings out a flashlight, starts to move out to the patio. Sylvia clings to him as he looks.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Whispering, tense) Nothing there now.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: It was... (Indicating Martians) ...one of them!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: What was it like?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Drawing him back toward kitchen) I couldn't see much in the dark - but it was one!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: We're right in a nest of 'em! I've got to get a look at them. He pulls away from Sylvia and works quickly at a shattered wall, making an opening. From the other side of the room comes the SOUND of shifting debris. Sylvia calls a warning. Clayton spins, backing to join her. They shelter in the kitchen doorway, watching cautiously. The thrusting and RATTLING of displaced wood and plaster continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their VIEWPOINT. Through the debris appears a long, slender mechanism in the shape of a flexible metal- lic tubing. At the head of it is an enlarged section which splits and slides back, disclosing a bright lens - like an eye, but larger. It begins to quest about the room, glittering in the deep shadow.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON AND SYLVIA
dialogues.text: He is fascinated. She is frozen with fear.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Bated) It's looking for us!  189. 190. 191. 191la. 192. She pulls him down behind the upset dinette table, jammed in a corner with other debris.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN SCANNING EYE
dialogues.text: It is divided into three striated lenses, each faintly colored with one of the optical primaries - red, blue or green. It comes through the doorway. It turns ceaselessly around and back again on a sheathed universal joint, making a faint CLICKING SOUND on each movement. Questing. Suspicious. Reflected in each lens is a tinted, peculiarly distorted view of the wrecked kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Huddled behind the table, watching through a crack.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: CAMERA PICKS UP the plastic-covered nose of the machine, within which the honeycombed circle has now become a luminous screen. On this translucent surface, projected from inside, is a curiously twisted picture of the kitchen - as transmitted by the scanning eye in the house below.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Clayton has picked up a pebble of broken plaster. He flips it against the ceiling of the living room beyond. He grabs Sylvia, pulling her down.

dialogues.speaker: SCANNING EYE
dialogues.text: The eye is turning around and back as Clayton's pebble and a little broken plaster dribble from the ceiling. The eye snakes upward to look. It comes down again. Slowly, suspiciously, it lowers to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: She is clutching him. He comes up a little, pokes cautiously where plaster is broken from the wall and peers into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton's VIEWPOINT. The mechanical eye is in the middle of the floor, turning around and back.  194. 195. Watching. Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: He covers the peephole with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Maybe they aren't too sure we're here.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Bated) They could be as curious about us as we are about them.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Maybe (Looks up) Maybe they want to take us alive.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: A Martian machine is moving through the mist in b.g. The one in the farmyard has moved nearer. The honey- combed circle is alight, showing the picture of the kitchen in the house. Suddenly this goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is using the peephole to the living room again.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Whispering - sharp) It's pulling out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEWPOINT from kitchen. The sheath is closing over the eye. The flexible tubing is withdrawing. It disappears.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: He gets up, comes cautiously from the kitchen, with Sylvia following. She grasps his arm.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Gasping) Let's get out of here! He gestures her to silence, moves toward the wall and the opening he had made. She peers fearfully out through the broken patio door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (At the door, shocked) They've blocked it!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (At opening in wall) It's blocked here, too! (Furiously clawing at the hole) They've pushed up earth or something all around outside. (Moving to fireplace) Here, this way...! He snatches an axe from the woodbox by the fireplace, jabbing between fallen ceiling beams. Sylvia looks fearfully around.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: CAMERA WHIPS UP from them. The Martian eye is hanging in the dimness above their heads, through a split in the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Look out!! Clayton sees it, leaps, slashing with the axe. A loose beam is dislodged in a shower of dust and frag- ments, falling across the tubing and the eye, pinning it to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: As he holds a foot on the tubing behind the eye, hacking with the axe. He cuts the lens clear. The rest of the mechanism is withdrawn fast, snaking up into the debris.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: We've got to get out now - fast! (Grabs up metal shape containing the eye) This is something tangible to work on.... (Excited, exultant) It'll tell us a lot about them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps to where he was working, hacking furiously with the axe, careless of noise now. CLAYTON (Cont'd) I've got to get to Pacific-Tech - quick!  201. 203. 204.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: SHOOTING past Clayton. She comes into SCENE behind him, pulling on a loose beam to give him room, using a piece of cloth to protect her hands. Behind her is a door leading to the den. It is broken, sprung from its hinges. CAMERA MOVES IN past Clayton as out of the dark cavity behind Sylvia comes a hand that is more than a hand, on an arm that is thin, lean, with degenerate muscu- lature. Thick veins cross it, pulsating. Back of it is a dim form. The hand-shape has three fingerlike suckers. They fasten on Sylvia's shoulder, spreading, huge. Her eyes and mouth open in horror. She tries to scream but her vocal cords are paralyzed, shocked. She is drawn back, drops the loose beam. Then she forces a SOUND between her lips. Clayton hears and leaps to help her, sending the beam of his flash- light at the figure behind her.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH
dialogues.text: We see a head, hairless, reddish like the planet itself, crossed by protruding veins which pulsate. Dominant is a single multi-lensed eye with colored pupils. The Martian is staggered by the light. He lifts his strange, suckered hands to ward it off.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Clayton turns with Sylvia to escape. The Martian lunges after them. Clayton turns the flashlight on the figure again. It stops, staggered. Clayton flings the axe and the Martian reels back as the axe hits. An unhuman SCREAMING sounds as it disappears back into the cavity. This continues overscene as Clayton swings Sylvia to the opening in the ceiling. He snatches up the piece of cloth Sylvia dropped, then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sylvia comes up through the sloping floor, slides to- ward a broken window, its frame sprung half out of the wall. Clayton slides after her, through the dormer window. They drop out between frame and wall. The SCREAMING continues.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The unhuman SCREAMING comes overscene, wild. We see  207. 208. 210. the red leg of the sentinel Martian, which is moving. In b.g. a machine is on the ground, misted. From an opening comes a yellowish, strange-colored beam. Visible in this are three moving creatures. Squat. Thick through. Everything about them sags downward under air weight and the pull of gravity. In f.g., Clayton and Sylvia flee wildly from the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two run from the direction of the house, smashing through a burned hedge, their feet stirring hot ashes and bright sparks in the darkness. The SCREAMING trails away.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN MACHINE
dialogues.text: The sentinel Martian has moved back from the house and is hitting it with a heat-ray. Beyond, in the night sky, the green streak of a multiple meteor sud- denly slants down. Glowing, sinister. Another slows, falling at the same angle. Both loom big before they hit the dark earth in turn and disappear behind the curtain of the ground mist. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An establishing shot.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOVERNMENT BLDG.
dialogues.text: CAMERA on wall lettering: DEPT. OF DEFENSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SHOOTING DOWN on an enormous table map of the world, scattered with black patches, indicating dead areas cleaned out by the Martians. Attack arrows extend from these. Metal - each with a bright, min- iature Martian machine. Around the edge of the map are WACs and special personnel constantly enlarging the blacked-out areas, pushing arrows forward as the Martians advance. The map indicates that the world is fighting for its existence. Spain is dead from  210a. 211. Valencia to Seville. Martians occupy the west of France up to Nantes. They're thick from Cherbourg across Belgium, Holland. The Italian boot is blacked out near Rome. Dark patches are in Greece, Yugo- slavia. In the southeast corner of England; in South Wales, Scotland and in Ireland from Tralee to Cork. They're in Sweden, Lithuania, Marrakesh, Tripoli, Egypt, South Africa and strategic places in the U.S.S.R. In the Levant and India, Malaya and Australia. Some dead areas are large. Some small. But the small ones grow larger all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A reception area occupies the floor around the map on the table. In this area, and in rooms off it, are batteries of teletypes, phones, wirephoto machines. Present are high Army, Air Force, Navy and Marine Corps brass, with a colorful scattering of worried foreign attaches - phoning, conferring, arguing. Seated personnel receive messages and use phones to direct the workers at the map. CAMERA MOVES IN on a big group near a wall covered with pull-down maps, listening to General Mann. His aide stands near, holding colored chalks. There is a control-bank of TV screens close by, lifeless.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Shooting past General Mann. We see high brass, all stars and staff insignia. The only civilian is the SECRETARY OF DEFENSE - neat, without fat, disting- uished, badger-gray hair, cool. He stands beside the CHIEF OF STAFF - balding, seven rows of decorations and five stars; a tight-lipped man with calculating eyes. The rest are mature tacticians and fighters. They include the FRENCH ATTACHE - rugged, tough. The ITALIAN ATTACHE - fat, suave. The BRITISH ATTACHE has a trim mustache, three rows of ribbons, graying hair. The incessant SOUNDS of phone calls, teletypes, quick orders come over SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: And this much is certain -- it is vital to prevent the Martian machines linking up. Once they do, they adopt an extraordinary military tactic. (Forceful - indicating map) You can see from those blacked-out areas that they're using it very effectively. They form a crescent...  212. 213.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: He uses colored chalk to draw a thick, crescent- shaped line on the blackboard. He continues drawing, illustrating his words.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: They anchor it at one end, and sweep on until they've cleared a quadrant... He draws three crescent-shaped lines to a quadrant, showing the movement of the Martians.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: ...Then they anchor the opposite end-- and reverse direction! As the strange diagram progresses across the black- board, it takes on an unearthly, centipedular aspect.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: They slash across country like scythes, wiping out everything that's trying to get away from them!

dialogues.speaker: AND CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: As Staff Colonel hands messages to the Chief.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: That explains why communication is cut the moment their machines begin to move.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: (Reading a message) Madrid has just blacked out!! Nothing more coming through.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: The same thing that happened on our Pacific Coast. (Calling) Anything from them yet?

dialogues.speaker: STAFF COLONEL
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Secretary. We've had nothing from San Francisco for over five hours.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MAJOR
dialogues.text: (Moving in, urgent) Those pictures are ready now, sir! All turn at once to follow him.  214.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MAJOR
dialogues.text: I've included that wirephoto from Paris, Mr. Secretary.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: (Glancing toward map) Are we still in touch with Paris?

dialogues.speaker: WAC
dialogues.text: (After a moment) No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ALCOVE
dialogues.text: as the group files in. No seats in the alcove. No lights. CAMERA FAVORS the foreign attaches.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN ATTACHE
dialogues.text: (Gesturing - in French) We set cannon wheel to wheel above Napoli. They melted them like candles.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH ATTACHE
dialogues.text: (To Italian attache - in French - with gestures) Our planes dived at them. All that happened -- (A sweep of the hands) -- They crumple like papier-mache! During this, the Staff Major snaps his fingers. A pictures hits the screen.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MAJOR
dialogues.text: This film clip was flown in from the West Coast... Golden Gate Bridge. A Martian machine is coming off the bridge, out from under one of the 750-foot towers. STAFF MAJOR (Cont'd) This other is from New York. One of them crossed from the New Jersey side... We see a Martian machine on the waterfront, moving caught against the New York skyline, using a ray against a skyscraper. STAFF MAJOR (Cont'd) (As film cuts off) And here are the wirephotos.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Everyone turns from the screen to a tall box with a tilted glass top.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MAJOR
dialogues.text: (Going on) This is the Paris wirephoto. It must be the last thing out of there! CAMERA MOVES IN on the glass. In a still picture transparescy, we see the Eiffel Tower collapsing. There is a Martian machine in a lower corner. A ray has blasted three of the tower's legs and is just hitting a fourth.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH ATTACHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (In French) My God!

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MAJOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: And this is another - from Rio de Janeiro. Day. Seen from the harbor, with the Corcovado Peak and huge Christus statue against the sky. A Martian machine shows among the ruins at the waterfront. STAFF MAJOR'S VOICE (Cont'd) Outside London. The River Thames, near Windsor Castle. Windsor Castle in b.g. A Martian machine wading the river, half-hidden by misty steam. A heat-ray hit- ting the water. In f.g., an overturned rowboat and people in the water.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH ATTACHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The water's boiling from the Martian heat-ray!

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MAJOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ...And here's that Los Angeles picture!

dialogues.speaker: ALCOVE
dialogues.text: The light from the viewbox tints their faces blue.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MAJOR
dialogues.text: This is a sonic-radar picture, taken from extreme altitude. It shows de- tails of the Martian nest outside Los Angeles. CAMERA MOVES IN on the viewing glass.  217. 219.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MAJOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Their machines show as round blobs. Newly fallen cylinders are elongated. We see an odd, blue-tinted photo. It shows a clear pattern of small, shining shapes. Sentinel Martians make the outer points of a triangle. Inside these are smaller triangles, formed where multiple cylin- ders have come down.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF'S VOICE
dialogues.text: We know there are three cylinders to each group. Three machines to every cylinder... (Appalled) That's over fifty machines right here!

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: (To Secretary) Mister Secretary - if they link up with those others near Fresno...

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: All right - I've seen enough! He strides from the alcove - CAMERA FOLLOWING - and moves to the big map on the table and looks down at it. The others follow and gather around.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATIONS MAP
dialogues.text: Blacked-out areas increasing. Arrows being moved. Activity all along the map.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: The Secretary looks up to the others.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: There's only one thing that will stop the Martians! We've held back pre- viously because of the danger of radiation to civilians. Now there's no choice. (To Chief of Staff) The United Nations has voted authority to the United States. The White House will confirm an order to use the Atom bomb.
(Nodding - decisive) Then our first target will be the initial landing place outside Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: I'll request the scientists from Pacific-Tech to monitor the drop. (Toward General Mann) We'll clear the area all around. After that we'll hit them all over the world. I'll have long-range bombers alerted, loaded and standing by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting from the portale, past an iron railing and a pillar with a framed plan of the campus, marked: PACIFIC INSTITUTE OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of Pacific-Tech doctors and assistants are sorting out anti-radiation suits, rubber gloves, Geiger counters, masks and special equipment. They are modern scientists, natural in manner, alert. Dr. Pryor - high man in aerodynamics - turns sharply as Clayton comes in with Sylvia. A gray-haired man faces around with him - DR. DuBROCK, Nobel prize- winner in physics.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PRYOR
dialogues.text: Forrester - everybody's been looking for you!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I know. We've walked halfway from Corona! Finally found an abandoned truck. Miss Van Buren - this is Dr. Pryor ... Dr. DuBrock... (Talking right on, bringing out Martian âeyeâ and stained cloth) What's this I hear about the A-bomb?

dialogues.speaker: DR. PRYOR
dialogues.text: We're going in right afterwards! Study its effect. DR. DuBROCK We leave in half an hour.  (Looking) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: DR. PRYOR
dialogues.text: A king-size fish eye?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: We took this off the Martians. All move in sharply as he sets the eye on a table. DR. PENNINGTON - astro-physics and optics - examines it closely.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Going on, quick) It'll tell us a lot about their metals and alloys.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PENNINGTON
dialogues.text: (Roused) If this is a lens, we can find out something about their optics.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PRYOR
dialogues.text: Interesting...very interesting...

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Showing cloth, pointing to stain) And this is the blood of a Martian!

dialogues.speaker: BLOOD
dialogues.text: Pallid pink. Full of tiny crystals.

dialogues.speaker: DR. GRATZMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I've never seen blood as anaemic as this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a big microscope with twin eye-pieces. DR. GRATZMAN is looking up from it - biochemist and research man, alert, red-haired. CAMERA BEGINS TO PULL BACK as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: DR. GRATZMAN
dialogues.text: They may be mental giants, but by our standards, they're physically degenerate. Most of the Pacific-Tech scientists are grouped with  him at a bench where the stained cloth is under examination; Clayton and Sylvia with them. Ina corner is an epidiascope; Dr. Pennington is rigging the Martian 'eye' to this. The instrument has a big screen. There is a wall-board chalked with notes and form- ulae. High-pressure cylinders - one red, one green - in a wheeled carrier. Benches with asbestos tops and discarded apparatus - mercury jars, holders, switches. Big, gay-colored electronic tubes. DR. DuBROCK (To Sylvia, commenting) That hand - fingers like suckers! (Amused) It sounds as though they may have evolved from fish.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: They're cold-blooded enough!

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: "Baldy' Bilderbeck, mathematician and top-drawer man in nuclear physics.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BILDERBECK
dialogues.text: (Commenting mildly) Isn't it curious how everything about them seems to be in threes?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Their eyes have three lenses and three distinct pupils. And strong light shocks them.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PENNINGTON
dialogues.text: They're not accustomed to it! Sunlight on Mars is about half as strong as we get it. Add their clouds and dust and it amounts to no more than twilight. (To Clayton) We've rigged this epidiascope to reflect whatever your Martian lense picks up. (Clicks switch) Move in a little ... Thank you. CAMERA ANGLES to favor Clayton, Dr. Pryor and Dr. Bilderbeck as they ease nearer. Light from the epidiascope screen shows on their faces. Its density changes. Suddenly, everyone gasps, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PENNINGTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: That's how the Martians see us...!  225.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Shooting CLOSE PAST the three to a terrifying image of themselves on the big glass screen. Colors hideously changed. Eyes enormous and peculiar. Green faces. Hands elongated. Fingers like bony talons with blue claws. Proportions gone crazy, and all movement exaggerated. There is a moment of horrified silence. DR. DuBROCK'S VOICE If that's how they see us, no wonder they want to kill us on sight!

dialogues.speaker: DR. BILDERBECK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: If I saw creatures like that I'd want to kill them myself.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Evidently there's a shift in the spec- trum. And color absorption of the Martian retina is completely different from our own. (Amused) But maybe they look good to each other!

dialogues.speaker: DR. PENNINGTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Let's find out why they were so curious about you, Miss Van Buren. The others move back and Sylvia seems to surge on to the glass screen. Her face is a nightmare mask, violently colored. She recoils in a little shocked movement.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (Lightly) Well, well -- a Martian's idea of beauty! DR. DuBROCK'S VOICE (Calling) Time we got started, gentlemen! The glass screen picks up a distorted image of Clayton's face as he moves to Sylvia and turns with her to go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all moving toward the door. Clayton pauses by the microscope, glancing toward Gratzman.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Touching cloth - thoughtfully) This Martian blood...  225B. 226. (Suddenly suggesting) Let's make a quick analysis and see what we've got!

dialogues.speaker: GRATZMAN
dialogues.text: (Looking at him - thinking) It might give us something. Sylvia glances at them in turn, not understanding, but sensing the importance of what they are saying. Pennington pauses behind them.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Nodding - glancing from cloth to Gratzman) Something we could use...

dialogues.speaker: PENNINGTON
dialogues.text: Let it go. If you're interested in Martian blood, you'll be able to get all you want right after the plane drops the bomb! They all start toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great six-jet flying wing bomber races down the runway and takes to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA is CLOSE on the lips and mouth of a RADIO REPORTER for the Pacific Broadcasting Company as he speaks rapidly and dramatically into a microphone.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: The target for the A-bomb drop is this nest of Martian machines in the Puente Hills - where more of these meteors came down early last evening. The SHOT WIDENS to show the Reporter -- dishevelled, tired, dirty -- with a portable tape-recorder slung over his shoulder. He moves forward, CAMERA FOLLOW- ING, to disclose Sylvia, gazing through field glasses. The Reporter exits, still talking rapidly. Sylvia lowers the glasses momentarily, then looks through them again. CAMERA leaves her, PANNING. The mouth of the vehicular tunnel is on the slope of  a high ridge, about halfway up to the summit, so that a view from the tunnel itself is one of sky only. Right at the mouth of the tunnel, the highway makes an abrupt turn to enter, and the outer side of the roadway is protected by the usual concrete buffer wall. This has been augmented by the military with massive sandbag breastworks to protect those in the tunnel and the necessary observers in forward posi- tions from enemy action from the valley below. With- in the tunnel proper, CAMERA PICKS UP the scientists from Pacific-Tech, who are gathered in a cul-de-sac in the tunnel wall. Doctors DuBrock, Pennington and Bilderbeck have already got into their colored anti- radiation suits. Doctors Pryor and Gratzman are present with sundry assistants. Gloves, masks, and special equipment are being laid out. Clayton is putting on a suit. A jeep stands by. During this:

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: A plane will pinpoint the target for the drop from six miles up. Conditions are perfect. The bomb will be about ten times more powerful than the one used at Hiroshima. Nothing like it has ever been exploded before, and we're going to be pretty darn close -- but there are observers down in the valley in a forward bunker and they'll be a lot nearer than us! CAMERA MOVES to PICK UP, near the outer breastworks, Army, Navy and Air Force brass, with special observers from the Atomic Energy Commission, and a First-Aid unit. To one side is a group of high officers and officials, for liaison and observation from Allied Nations within the roster of the united Nations. Everyone is equipped with field glasses. Observing officers use them constantly and talk quietly, tense- ly. There is a BUZZ of comment in foreign tongues from the United Nations Group. A spread of loud- speakers is mounted on a jeep. Other vehicles include a Radar Scanning truck with antenna cocked skyward, constantly scanning. REPORTER'S VOICE (Cont'd) There must be a couple of million people back of us in the shelter of the San Gabriel hills -- waiting to find out whether they can go home again! This will decide the fate of civilization and all humanity -- whether we live or die may depend on what happens here!

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER VOICE
dialogues.text: (ECHOING in the tunnel) Attention, please...Thuh-ree minutes to bomb time!  226A. 227. CAMERA PICKS UP General Mann with a group of officers and staff of Sixth Army Command, behind a big breast- work. Nearby is a field telephone unit. Beyond are cameramen in battle dress. The Radio Reporter moves into SCENE, talking in to his mike.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Direct cable communication is being maintained with Washington, and from there to key centers around the world, but there's no radio communication at all - even with the bombing plane that's coming over. All radio is dead. Which means that these tape-recordings I'm making are for the sake of history -- if any!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big delta-wing bomber takes off and speeds toward the clouds, heading for the target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton, Drs. DuBrock, Bilderbeck. All are helping each other with their anti-radiation suits. Sylvia moves into SCENE and assists Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: General Mann says Washington is cer- tain the Martians are aiming at complete saturation. They intend to take over the entire earth. DR. DuBROCK And Bilderbeck has calculated exactly how long we've got before they do it! All look at Bilderbeck.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BILDERBECK
dialogues.text: (Mildly) If the A-bomb fails, that is.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PENNINGTON
dialogues.text: It won't.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BILDERBECK
dialogues.text: (Evenly) If it should fail, the Martians can conquer the earth in six days. There is a moment's pause.  228.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Quietly) The same number of days it took to create it. All look at her.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER VOICE
dialogues.text: Attention, please...two minutes to bomb time!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON AND SYLVIA
dialogues.text: She helps adjust the cuffs at his wrist, and his belt. Then, after a moment, making it casual:

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Is it possible to go in right after the explosion?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Yes, with these suits. We've used them before on atomic tests... Odd- looking, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Very futuristic. (Smiling) Yours doesn't really go with that butch haircut!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Hand through hair) I could wear it longer -- but it's less trouble this way.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: My kid brother has one. You know why?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Yes ... Fits better in a football helmet.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Amazed, staring) How'd you guess?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Smiling) That's the kind of a kid brother you'd have!

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER VOICE
dialogues.text: Attention, please! One minute to bomb time. Take shelter!  229. 229A. 230. 231. 232.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All move into position behind the barriers. Staff officers consult watches. Some try to sight the plane.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER VOICE
dialogues.text: Fifty seconds to zero. Stand by! If you have no goggles, turn away. Remember, the heat flash and afterblast are danger- ous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The A-bomb plane circles above the clouds, heading for the Martians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The antenna scans the sky ceaselessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An officer and a sergeant are tensely watching the radar screen. The pip suddenly resolves into a dot.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: There's the plane! The sergeant runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA is on the Radar truck. The sergeant bolts out the rear door, runs toward General Mann and the scien- tists, CAMERA PANNING with him. All are standing tensely, looking OFF toward the Martian nest.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER VOICE
dialogues.text: Forty seconds to zero.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: SHOOTING in toward the tunnel. Perched on a scrub tree, f.g., is an oriole, singing. Clayton and Sylvia, the scientists, General Mann and others. The sergeant reaches General Mann.

dialogues.speaker: LOUSPEAKER VOICE
dialogues.text: Thirty seconds to zero.  234. 235. From here on, every second is marked by a CLICKING metroname-like beat. Every fifth second is empha- sized by the VOICE over the loudspeaker.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: (To General Mann) We've sighted the bomber, sir! General Mann and the others look toward the sky.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER VOICE
dialogues.text: Twenty-five seconds to zero. DR. DuBROCK (Glancing 0.s. - suddenly) Look... look! Field glasses swing quickly in the direction of the Martian nest.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: It is a hell of a scene. Sentinel Martian machines are darting back and forth on the perimeter of the massed group. All the machines glitter and glow in the waning daylight, suddenly imbued with a furious activity. Cobalt jets are stabbing upward from every machine.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER VOICE
dialogues.text: Twenty seconds to zero.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Favoring Dr. DuBrock and the scientists. DR. DuBROCK They must have sighted it, too!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The indlvidual electro-magnetic envelopes expand, merge and grow rapidly to form blue-tinged bubbles clinging to the ground, still expanding. Racing up from each machine to form part of an over-all canopy.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER VOICE
dialogues.text: Fifteen seconds to zero. Thin blue-colored jets stand like rods above the trees, pulsating furiously, lifting the envelopes until they are enormous billows in the sky. Every- thing inside them takes on a different color.  237. 238.

dialogues.speaker: ABOUT THE MOUTH OF THE TUNNEL
dialogues.text: Everyone sheltering behind the breastworks and in the cul-de-sacs and behind vehicles in the tunnel. Clayton, Sylvia, the scientists - Navy, Army, Air Force brass, Foreign representatives, cameramen, tense and goggled. The yellow-breasted oriole, still singing.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER VOICE
dialogues.text: (Measured - clear) Ten seconds to zero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pacific-Tech men in f.g. Everybody without goggles turns away, head bent. All duck behind sandbags.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER VOICE
dialogues.text: Nine - eight - seven - six - five - four - three - two - one - ZERO! A blinding flash of light murders all color.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: A blunted spear of light has lanced out of the sky. It explodes into a gigantic, reddish heat-flash. An elephantine swirl of dust and smoke, shot with orange and peach and pink, engulfs the Martian Machines. Then comes the SOUND of a cataclysmic explosion and the SCREAM of a great wind.

dialogues.speaker: EFFECT OF THE BOMB
dialogues.text: a. Brass ducked behind sandbags. Dust, branches, papers, debris slashing through the air. b. A Signal Corps corporal, incautiously ex- posed, being blown end-over-end. c. The Radar Truck almost topples over under the concussion of the blast, antenna torn loose and falling. da. Clayton, hanging onto sandbags with one hand, clings to Sylvia with the other. e. A FULL SHOT inside the tunnel. Every object is limned sharply and brutally in the white- hot glare of atomic fission. The deafening ROAR of the explosion ECHOES and RE-ECHOES  243. along the tunnel. f. Special Effect - the glare outlines a cowering group inside a highway gas station as the plate glass windows shatter over them. g. A Series of CUTS - EARTHQUAKE EFFECT (STOCK). A bus overturns - a car is wrecked - a house and sheds collapse - utility poles sway, wires snapping and sparking - buildings shudder and shower masonry - bridges and oil derricks sway and collapse - people flee, panic-stricken. h. A hillside - families cower in the shelter of rocks, stark faces to the glaring sky. i. Special Effect (Matte painting). The San Gabriel Hills, showing thousands upon thousands of families massed in the barrancas and gul- lies - a scene reminiscent of Mount Rubidoux of an Easter morning. As the bomb glares, a GASP of human terror and agony joins with the ROAR of the great concussion wave. j. The titanic mushrooming pillar of smoke and dust obscures the Martian nest.

dialogues.speaker: GEN. MANN
dialogues.text: The General is at the field telephone. The blast is swirling all around.

dialogues.speaker: GEN. MANN
dialogues.text: (At phone - shouting) Hello! Hello, there! What can you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two military observers - in concussion helmets and anti-radiation suits - peering through periscope slits in a heavily sandbagged bunker. Wind blows dust in through the slits.

dialogues.speaker: OBSERVER
dialogues.text: (Gasping - into phone) It's beginning to clear out there, sir!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: The blue envelopes are shrinking upon themselves, going down, color deepening. They are unpunctured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The observer yells into his field telephone.

dialogues.speaker: OBSERVER
dialogues.text: There's something moving...!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: Out of the coiling dust and smoke a Martian machine is gliding. Another follows. A third shows.

dialogues.speaker: OBSERVER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (Yelling) They haven't even been touched!

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: The Pacific-Tech men run into the breastwork, Clayton and Sylvia with them. The suction blast whips and swirls, dust filling the air. CAMERA FAVORS the General, using field glasses.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: (Shaken) It didn't stop them...

dialogues.speaker: DR. PRYOR
dialogues.text: They knew what to expect! DR. DuBROCK (Excited) They're way ahead of us electronically. They've had the atom bomb and forgotten it!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: (Desperate) Guns - tanks - bombs - they're like toys against them. We can't go on ordering men to attack...! 247. WIDER ANGLE - GROUP - SYLVIA IN F.G. Army, Navy and Air Force Brass coming over, listen- ing, anxious. The wind fades.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PRYOR
dialogues.text: They'll exterminate every living thing!

dialogues.speaker: DR. PENNINGTON
dialogues.text: So what do we do -- run about like ants until they hunt us down?  sylvia

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MANN
dialogues.text: We'll establish a line and fight them all the way back to the mountains!

dialogues.speaker: DR. BILDERBECK
dialogues.text: (Mildly again) But it can end only one way We're beaten. looks at him, moves away. Clayton follows. MOVES IN on Dr. DuBrock and Dr. Bilderbeck. DR. DuBROCK (Quietly, looking out) Six days, you said ... six days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring Sylvia, as Clayton comes to her. Dr. DuBrock is approaching from b.g. Sylvia looks up at the empty branch where the oriole was perched.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Maybe they won't kill all the birds. DR. DuBROCK Washington issued orders - in event the A-bomb failed - immediately evacuate all cities under attack! (Looking out toward Martians) And they're moving in on Los Angeles now!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: They'll stamp the city flat! DR. DuBROCK (To Clayton) If we take all the instruments we can establish a base in the Rocky Mountains...

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Nodding - looking o.s.) A forlorn hope - but there is a chance.

dialogues.speaker: GRATZMAN
dialogues.text: It might give us time to search out some weakness in the Martians.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I believe we can get a lead from their anaemic blood. DR. DuBROCK (Glancing at Clayton)  You mean some biological approach...?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Forcefully) We know now that we can't beat their machines -- but we can beat them! (Looking o.s. again) They are mortal beings...The only question is whether we have time enough to do anything!

dialogues.speaker: GRATZMAN
dialogues.text: (To DuBrock) If we get what transportation we can, and pick up instruments and books from Pacific-Tech... DuBROCK (To Sylvia) Could you help us? Drive for us?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Of course. DR. DuBROCK (Hurrying o.s.) Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Quietly, watching Sylvia) The Rockies...! You'd rather get back to that big family of yours in Minnesota, wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I wonder if they're going through this too...? Clayton looks at her sympathetically, not speaking.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Going on) I probably wouldn't be able to get to them if I tried...

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: You'll be all right with us.... (Looking out again) ...for as long as anybody's got!

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Touching his arm) Don't let's lose each other. He tucks a hand under her arm, reassuring, turning away with her.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (Wryly, smiling) Because then I really would feel lost!

dialogues.speaker: SIRENS
dialogues.text: a. CLOSE SHOT - Siren - City Hall in b.g. It begins to blast, full-throated, screaming its warning. b. MEDIUM SHOT - Ext. Street Corner. Traffic light in f.g. with air raid siren on top. It starts to howl. ANGLE showing traffic in b.g. Pedestrians turn quickly. Cars drive erratically, pulling toward the curb. c. Ext. Cornice of Office Bldg. A nest of sirens on the rim of the roof, wailing. d. MEDIUM SHOT - Ext. Cahuenga Pass at Freeway Entrance. Sirens on a light pole take up the warning. Cars head toward curbs, then speed away, turning against traffic. Confusion. e. MEDIUM SHOT - Ext. Firehouse. Sirens wail. A red Underwriters sedan crashes out into the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police car coming slowly down the street. Red blinker working. Siren going furiously. It has a windshield sticker: Civil Defense. Following the police car is a pick-up, with a loud- speaker horn. A man with a Civil Defense armband stands in the truck, shouting into mike.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER
dialogues.text: Now listen carefully. This is a military evacuation order. All populated areas are to be abandoned. It is imperative that you leave the city.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK AND WARDENS
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES with loudspeaker trucker. C.D. wardens, wearing old-style steel helmets, shouting to pedes- trians and cars. Some run to the houses. In b.g. people dash from their homes, gathering up kids, piling possessions on cars, yelling at one another.  253. A few cars spurt out of driveways and barrel off. A chorus of wailing sirens overscene.

dialogues.speaker: C.D. OFFICIALS
dialogues.text: (Over loudspeaker) The Martians are coming - Take what you can carry and get out â Take food and water with you - Get away from all popu- lated areas - Go to the desert or the mountains - The City's being evacuated - Get going for your lives!

dialogues.speaker: ALARM
dialogues.text: Giant rubber, aircraft and cracking plants caught as shifts break. Thousands of men racing for their cars. Sirens SCREAMING o.s. (Second Unit with con- cealed 16 mm camera. Stunt men beefing it up.)

dialogues.speaker: EVACUATION EFFECT, (1)
dialogues.text: Everything moving from right to left on the screen - all going one way, merged with FAST DISSOLVES. Haste and urgency. a. Low angle, cars flooding a highway. Bundles on fenders, roofs. Rolling bumper to bumper, fast. b. People piling onto buses as they pull out, toting suit cases and bundles. c. Deserted ice-cream wagon, wheel broken, tipped over against a wall. Kid on the back step, stuffing himself with ice cream. da. Sweating C.D. officials and cops waving traffic past, urging it faster - faster. e. Refugees cramming aboard a pullman. f. Man crowding last bundle onto a car roof; woman yelling at him from the car. As he starts away, he sees he has a flat tire. g. Ext. General Hospital. Nurses, internes, evacuating stretcher and ambulatory cases to ambulances in f.g. h. A single line of refugees trudging over a firebreak in the hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overscene is the distant SOUND of the Martian approach - roaring explosions, the thunder of destruction and gunfire. The scene itself is desper- ate with urgency and activity. Scientists working frantically to load books, heavy instruments, papers, files - even a blackboard from which there is no time to copy the formulae it bears. For transporta- tion they have a small moving van, a school bus, stake truck, two light pick-ups and four cars. As we come into scene, the moving van roars past us to the street. Beyond this, the last baggage is being slammed aboard the yellow school bus. Dr. DuBrock waves it away. It comes PAST CAMERA - Sylvia driving - as Clayton climbs up behind the wheel of the stake truck.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE STAKE TRUCK
dialogues.text: Clayton reaches for the starter button as Gratzman hurries past.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Calling) Gratzman! -- Gratzman! Did you get those biotics?

dialogues.speaker: GRATZMAN
dialogues.text: No. I thought you had them.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: All right. I'll get them! (Drops off truck) (Shouts to DuBrock) Go ahead - go ahead! I'll catch up with you. He runs 0.s. Other vehicles start to move out as their frantic loading is completed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is in a state of abandonment and disorder. Clayton runs in. He grabs two big cartons, throws out their contents and hurriedly loads them with glass and packed plastic vials which have been left on one of the benches. He starts out again.

dialogues.speaker: YARD BEHIND PACIFIC-TECH
dialogues.text: It is littered with discarded material. All the other  257. 258. 259. 260. 261. 262. 263. vehicles have gone when Clayton runs to the stake truck. yard, the passenger seat. screams away. He is a lonely, desperate figure in the empty as he clambers aboard pushing his load across to He starts the motor. The truck

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motor roaring as Clayton steps on the gas. gear, peering ahead, anxious

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shifts to overtake Sylvia. The stake truck turning a corner onto a wide street, rolling fast, tires squealing. Clayton's brakes go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Braking hard. ahead. Standing on everything. Staring

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CITY STREET
dialogues.text: A mob has attacked and piled Others are swarming all over These vehicles begin to move and bumpers. The mob rushes

dialogues.speaker: STAKE TRUCK AND MOB
dialogues.text: Men jump up at both sides of the doors before Clayton can

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING through the windshield. from both sides of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: STAKE TRUCK AND MOB
dialogues.text: It is a strange mob. Men and women. aboard a P.E. bus. a couple of taxis. on, with men on roofs the stake truck. the cab, back up. wrenching open Men attacking Clayton Desperate. Piling over the open sides of the now halted truck, while Clayton fights behind the wheel. A man slides into his place. He is thrown out. CAMERA PANS the mob, fighting to get aboard - emptying the truck to make room. and papers shower down. The Scientific instruments crash to the road. Books truck gets under way. People hanging on outside are shoved off.  264. 266.

dialogues.speaker: BACK OF TRUCK
dialogues.text: A well-dressed man is clinging to a rear corner, perched precariously, holding a bag. Another man is struggling, elbowing him to make his own hold secure.

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED MAN
dialogues.text: (Desperate) Let me up there!

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (Shoving) Get off!

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED MAN
dialogues.text: (Hanging on, gasping) I'll give you five hundred dollars for your place! (Wild) I'll make it a thousand! Two!

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (Shoving him off) Money's no good no more, bud!

dialogues.speaker: ROADWAY
dialogues.text: His bag bursts open as he falls. Bills, gold coins, jewelry spills out. He scrambles to pick up his money. Running feet trample on it. Trample on him.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: He gets to his feet, winded, holding his ribs, gazing after the truck. Stragglers run past him. Only the well-dressed man is left behind, still grabbing for his valuables. Clayton gets his breath, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED MAN
dialogues.text: Strewn on the pavement is the precious debris the mob left. The shattered barrel of an electron micro- scope - biochemical vials, spilled and shattered - electric induction furnace - laboratory cameras - electronic tubes - microscopes - books - the jars and containers of organic chemistry. The well- dressed man is scrabbling among this wreckage as Clayton comes into SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Still gasping)  Did that mob grab the truck ahead of me? The man glances at him but doesn't answer. Clayton moves nearer. CLAYTON (Cont'd) (Desperate) Hey - there were a lot of Pacific-Tech men with those trucks! Did you see them?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I don't know. There was fighting up the street.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Still moving in) Did the mob get a school bus? A girl was driving it. The man is on his knees, grabbing, panting.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: If they saw it, they took it! They take anything on wheels. You can't buy transportation for love or money... (Pausing) Money...!

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING WELL-DRESSED MAN
dialogues.text: He sits back on his haunches, looking at the bills and coins in his hand. He looks from the bag to Clayton and back again, suddenly shaken and terribly shocked.

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED MAN
dialogues.text: My whole life's savings...Now it won't even buy a ride on a truck! Slowly he stands up. Suddenly he grabs a big fistful of bills and jewels from the bag.

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED MAN
dialogues.text: (Twisted) You want five thousand dollars... ten...twenty? (Tosses bills toward Clayton, throws down the bag) Help yourself -- there's a hundred thousand in there! He turns and starts after the mob. Clayton eyes the ruin around him. He picks up a shattered microscope, looking from it to the way he has come. Again he looks at the debris of the instruments, hopeless. He  270. turns to the way he was traveling and lets the micro- scope fall from his hand as he starts away, beginning to run. CAMERA ANGLES to PICK UP the money and broken instruments. It MOVES CLOSE on the shattered micro- scope as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserted. Late afternoon shadows. Littered with dropped garments. Doors stand open. Curtains flap at windows. Clayton is running, glancing back as an old, open car rattles into scene. Loaded with three families, their kids and two barking dogs. Bundles and baggage tied all over it. Clayton thumbs for a ride. Sprints and tries to leap on the running board. Hands shove him off. He falls. The car clatters on. Clayton gets up off the road and begins to run again. Two more cars come past CAMERA and race by him, over- loaded, driven recklessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton dog-trots into scene. It is beginning to get dark. We see debris from a hasty road-block placed by a mob - chairs, settee, furniture dragged out of a nearby store. To the side of the road is one of the pickups from Pacific-Tech, distinguished by its color, overturned, its load spilled, wheels buckled, jammed between a telephone pole and shop front. Strewn on the road are piles of papers, books, files and instruments thrown off the other Pacific-Tech vehicles. Clayton stares around, sees something and hurries to pick up a yellow board: SCHOOL BUS - Southridge. He holds it, looking around. The road is scattered with baggage thrown off the little bus. A car streaks past, heavily laden and going fast. Three bicyclists follow, pedaling hard, possessions tied all over themselves and their machines. One wobbles, but recovers. Clayton starts forward, hesitates, still holding the yellow board.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Suddenly shouting) DuBrock! (And then - wilder) Bilderbeck -- DuBrock! SYLVIA! No answer. He looks up at the sky and the unearthly flicker of the Martian rays. He glances at the board again. The first drops of rain hit it, driz- zling down. He drops it across the curb, moves  274. away toward the broken barrier, turning up his coat collar. CAMERA DOLLIES IN on the school bus sign, lying in the gutter.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHES
dialogues.text: The rain has stopped. The streets are wet and glistening. a. Rooftops and utility poles silhouetted against the smoky sky. Local explosions. Flashes of Martian rays and beams. b. Traffic thin, fast and frightened on a highway out of the city. c. Moving cars in CLOSER ANGLE. All overloaded. Carrying extra riders wherever they can perch - on fenders, bumpers, roofs. da. Refugees running down the cloverleaf off a freeway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A traffic light, not working. A mailbox overturned. There is a broken suitcase at one end of a rain- washed bus bench. Clayton enters, pausing by the bench. He is sweating, irresolute, as he looks around, breathing hard. He's worn out, walking on his heels. An MP Jeep - two MPs in it - rolls into SHOT, coming past the intersection. The driver sees Clayton, brakes hard.

dialogues.speaker: M.P. DRIVER
dialogues.text: Hey, you! Better get outa here!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I'm looking for some Pacific-Tech professors...

dialogues.speaker: M.P. DRIVER
dialogues.text: There's nobody left around here now.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Half to himself, desperately) We had a chance...We could have stopped them!  275. 277. (To the staring M.P.'s) The mob stole the trucks and smashed everything up. The fools! They cut their own throats! OTHER M.P. He's nuts. C'mon - jump in! The MP's look up.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: An overshot ray from some Martian machine slashes the air, high overhead. Squealing, pulsating. Vicious. Seen beyond the power and phone wires.

dialogues.speaker: CIVIC CENTER AND MARTIAN MACHINES
dialogues.text: a. Civic Center. Streets empty. Martian machines active in distant b.g. b. Martian machines, belly-deep in flame, rays and beams working. c. CLOSE ON a Martian machine among collapsing, burning buildings. It sends a beam slanting upward. d. CLOSE ON City Hall. Its top section is hit by the beam it falls, disintegrating into colored dust.

dialogues.speaker: INTERSECTION WITH SIGN
dialogues.text: The MP's are half-ducking from the menace of the overshot ray.

dialogues.speaker: M.P. DRIVER
dialogues.text: Hurry up! Jump in!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Appealing) There was a girl with them...If I could find her.... OTHER M.P. Jump in here, will you?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: She's kind of lost.

dialogues.speaker: M.P. DRIVER
dialogues.text: You look kinda lost yourself.  276. 279. 281.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (Looking o.s. - suddenly remembering) But I think I know where she'll be.... OTHER M.P. C'mon, c'mon! It's your last chance to get outta here! Clayton waves the jeep away and it roars off. He starts in the direction from which the jeep came, beginning to run.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: SPECIAL EFFECT - EXT. STREET (Same as 270) - (NIGHT) CAMERA is CLOSE on a muddy puddle of rainwater in the gutter. Floating in the muck is the yellow sign: SCHOOL BUS - SOUTHRIDGE. Angrily reflected on the surface of the water is the glaring sky, rays slashing, flames and explosions towering. Silent, except for the b.g. ROAR of destruction. No light except the glare from the sky. CAMERA PULLS BACK as the long, wavering shadow of a man moves across the sidewalk, looming larger and closer. His FOOTSTEPS ECHO in the deserted street. Then his feet enter the SHOT and pause by the puddle and the yellow board. CAMERA MOVES UP to disclose Clayton in CLOSE figure, looking down at the sign. Slowly he looks OFF. CAMERA PANS away from him to show the street beyond. Smashed windows and looted shops. Cracked-up, abandoned vehicles. Discarded bundles. A jalopy has overturned against a fire hydrant and water geysers high in the air. Clay- ton re-enters the SHOT, running a little way, walking a little, then running again. He looks around as he goes, seeking a clue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathing hard, sweating. No life anywhere. Sprat from the broken hydrant drips from him. He trots toward a nearby corner.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: A REVERSE ANGLE, SHOOTING along a side street from the corner. Clayton enters, f.g., stops by a lamp post, looking ahead. Along the dimly lit street is a church. Faint light shows at the windows. Above  281la. 282. 282a. and beyond it is a burning ray-shot sky. As Clayton starts toward it, the distant SOUND OF VOICES SINGING is heard.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: A DOWN SHOT from high alongside the church steeple and belfry. The dark, Gothic outline of the tower looms huge in f.g. Below in the distance, the tiny figure of Clayton uncertainly approaches the church over the glistening pavement. The MUSIC of the VOICES GROWS LOUDER, but muffled and ECHOING through the structure of the steeple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton stumbles from f.g. toward the steps and doors of the church, CAMERA FOLLOWING. The MUSIC of the HYMN SWELLS, but is still muffled and indistinct. He climbs the steps, pushes open the doors. The MUSIC SWELLS to full volume, VOICES joined in suppli- cation to God. No one is seen but Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA is CLOSE on Clayton as he opens the doors and pauses, looking off. The SINGING reaches a CRESCENDO and dies away. The SHOT WIDENS and CAMERA PANS with Clayton to people standing near the door. Light in the church comes from kerosene lamps and candles placed wherever they will stand - on pew-ends, window-ledges. CAMERA FOLLOWS Clayton, as he looks anxiously about. The congregation is a scattered gathering of distressed humanity.
